questions.text: A 17-year-old girl comes to the physician because she had unprotected sexual intercourse the previous day. She states that she does not wish to become pregnant until she is in her thirties. She is concerned about becoming pregnant and requests the most effective emergency contraception. She has no history of serious illness. Menses have occurred at regular 28-day intervals since menarche at the age of 13 years. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 84 kg (185 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation regarding contraception for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral ulipristal acetate is an emergency contraception option with a failure rate of approx. 1%; the failure rate is relatively higher when used in the second half of the menstrual cycle and in individuals with overweight or obesity. For this patient, there is a more appropriate option for emergency contraception that has a lower failure rate and provides long-term contraception.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral levonorgestrel is available for emergency contraception without a prescription and is thus widely used. Studies have shown that oral levonorgestrel has a failure rate of approx. 2% when used as an emergency contraceptive and that the failure rate is relatively higher when used in the second half of the menstrual cycle and in women with overweight or obesity. For this patient, there is a more appropriate option for emergency contraception that has a lower failure rate and provides long-term contraception.

C) INCORRECT:

Although a progestin-containing subcutaneous implant is an excellent option for long-term contraception, this patient also requires emergency contraception, for which progestin-containing implants are neither approved nor recommended. Progestin-containing intrauterine devices, however, are an effective form of both emergency and long-term contraception.

D) INCORRECT:

Mifepristone is indicated for the medical abortion of an established pregnancy. Although mifepristone is used for emergency contraception in some countries, it is not currently approved for emergency contraception in the United States.

E) INCORRECT:

Combined oral contraceptive pills are widely used for long-term contraception. They can also be used in the form of a Yuzpe regimen for emergency contraception; however, combined oral contraceptive pills are the least effective option for this indication (failure rate is approx. 3–4%).

F) CORRECT:

Copper-containing intrauterine devices (IUDs) have been shown to be the most effective option for emergency contraception, with a failure rate of only approx. 0.1% regardless of the patient's BMI or the timing of emergency contraception with respect to ovulation. Recently, levonorgestrel IUDs have been shown to be just as effective as copper IUDs for emergency contraception and may also be associated with less discomfort. Since IUDs provide long-acting reversible contraception, they are a good option for women who require emergency contraception and do not wish to become pregnant in the near future. If a patient is considering pregnancy in the near future, or if the brief clinical procedure for IUD insertion is not feasible, other options for emergency contraception include oral levonorgestrel or ulipristal acetate, but these options are not as effective as copper or levonorgestrel IUDs, especially if the patient is overweight or obese or if these medications are used after ovulation (i.e., the second half of the menstrual cycle).

Although state laws vary, the majority of states allow minors to make their own decisions regarding contraception services and sexually transmitted infection screening and treatment.
questions.hint: This recommendation would be contraindicated if the patient had Wilson disease.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman comes to the physician to discuss contraceptive options. She is currently sexually active with one male partner, and they have not been using any contraception. She has no significant past medical history and takes no medications. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 15 years. She is allergic to latex and copper. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following contraceptive methods is contraindicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Depot medroxyprogesterone acetate (DMPA) is an injectable progestin administered every 3 months. Because DMPA lacks estrogen, it may be used in patients > 35 years of age who smoke.

B) INCORRECT:

The patient should avoid latex diaphragms because of her allergy. However, she could use a silicone or rubber diaphragm with spermicide.

C) INCORRECT:

Although estrogen-containing contraceptives are contraindicated in patients aged > 35 years with a smoking history (increases the risk of VTE), this woman is still a candidate for progestin-only contraceptives.

D) INCORRECT:

Although this patient reports a copper allergy and would not be a candidate for a copper intrauterine device (IUD), she could still receive a progestin IUD. Progestin IUDs provide long-acting reversible contraception and are also appropriate for smokers older than 35 years of age.

E) INCORRECT:

Although this patient should avoid latex condoms given her allergy, she could use nonlatex (e.g., polyurethane) condoms. With consistent and correct use, condoms have a minimal failure rate. Additionally, they reduce the risk of sexually transmitted infections.

F) CORRECT:

Combined oral contraceptive pills (COCs) are contraindicated in women ≥ 35 years of age who smoke due to an increased risk of VTE. Estrogen is associated with coagulopathy because it increases the plasma concentrations of several clotting factors and fibrinogen. Advancing age and smoking also affect blood clotting and circulation. Other absolute contraindications for the use of estrogen-containing COCs include cardiovascular diseases (e.g., coronary artery disease, deep vein thrombosis, stroke, hypertension), metabolic disorders (e.g., of the liver, insulin-dependent diabetes), estrogen-dependent tumors, SLE, and/or vasculitis.
questions.hint: This patient's age and smoking history increase her risk of venous thromboembolism (VTE) if she uses a particular form of contraception.

questions.text: An otherwise healthy 18-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of severe acne vulgaris over her face, upper back, and arms. Treatment with oral antibiotics and topical combination therapy with benzoyl peroxide and retinoid has not completely resolved her symptoms. Examination shows oily skin with numerous comedones, pustules, and scarring over the face and upper back. Long-term therapy is started with combined oral contraceptives. This patient's new medication significantly reduces the risk of developing which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Long-term COC use (≥ 5 years) is associated with an increased risk of developing cervical cancer. The mechanism by which they do this is unclear, but it is hypothesized that these medications increase the susceptibility of cervical cells to human papillomavirus infection (the main cause of cervical cancer) and/or decrease the ability of cervical cells to clear this infection.

B) CORRECT:

For female patients with continued severe acne vulgaris despite first-line therapies (e.g., oral antibiotics and topical combination therapy), COCs can be added. Besides having positive effects on acne vulgaris, the progestin contained in COCs opposes estrogen-driven endometrial hyperplasia, which reduces the risk of developing type 1 endometrial cancer. This risk decreases with a longer duration of COC use, and protection persists for many years after drug cessation. COCs also reduce the risk of developing ovarian cancer, possibly through reduced cell proliferation within the ovaries and fallopian tubes.

C) INCORRECT:

COC therapy is associated with an increased risk of developing deep vein thrombosis since estrogen induces transcription of clotting factors (II, VII, VIII, X, XII) and fibrinogen to promote clot formation.

D) INCORRECT:

COC therapy increases the risk of developing hypertension, although this risk minimizes shortly after drug cessation. The mechanism of oral contraception-induced hypertension is unclear but may be related to increased serum angiotensinogen concentrations.

E) INCORRECT:

COC therapy does not reduce the risk of developing breast cancer. However, there is controversy as to whether these medications actually increase the risk of developing breast cancer and, therefore, should be used with caution in patients with high risk for breast cancer development (e.g., due to BRCA mutations).

F) INCORRECT:

COCs increase the risk of developing hepatic adenomas. Although the mechanism is not fully understood, it may be related to estrogen-induced vascular dilation.
questions.hint: Progestin, a component of combined oral contraceptives (COCs), opposes the effects of estrogen.

questions.text: Ten days after delivering a healthy male newborn, a 28-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1, undergoes a postpartum follow-up evaluation. Labor and delivery were uncomplicated. One week after delivery, she was diagnosed with postpartum endometritis, for which she is currently receiving treatment with clindamycin and gentamicin. She had painful swelling of the breasts at the beginning of lactation, but frequent breastfeeding and warm compresses prior to breastfeeding improved her symptoms. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Prior to discharge, the patient asks about a reliable contraceptive method. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation at this time?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Spermicides are among the least effective methods of contraception. They are commonly combined with a diaphragm or cap but are often used incorrectly. Moreover, spermicides can cause vaginal burning, irritation, and allergic reactions. A safer method should be recommended to prevent unintended and short-interval pregnancy in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Intrauterine devices (IUDs) can be inserted as early as immediately postpartum and provide long-acting reversible contraception. While they can easily be removed when a pregnancy is desired, this patient is currently being treated for endometritis, a contraindication to an IUD. The insertion of an IUD is not recommended until the infection has been fully resolved. Other contraindications include genital malignancy, genital bleeding of unknown cause, gestational trophoblastic disease, septic abortion, active vaginitis or pelvic inflammatory disease, and certain uterine anomalies.

C) INCORRECT:

The basal body temperature method relies on a regular cycle with lower temperatures prior to ovulation and higher temperatures postovulation. Many events (e.g., fever, illness, breastfeeding, stress) may alter the basal body temperature, which makes this method unreliable. It is especially unreliable in postpartum women, most of whom do not have a normal biphasic temperature pattern.

D) CORRECT:

Contraceptive pills are a viable option for postpartum contraception. In breastfeeding women, progestin-only contraceptive pills (minipill) or progestin-only implants should be recommended, since estrogen-containing combined contraceptives may reduce breast milk production (by inhibition of prolactin activity) and enter the milk. Estrogen should also be avoided for the first 3 weeks postpartum because of its association with coagulopathy and a generally increased risk of thromboembolic events in the early postpartum period. Progestin prevents pregnancy by increasing the viscosity of cervical mucus and by impairing peristalsis of the fallopian tubes, leading to inhibited sperm ascension and egg implantation. In addition, it inhibits follicular maturation and may suppress ovulation. An intrauterine device is also a reasonable option in the postpartum period, but not in patients with active pelvic infection.

E) INCORRECT:

Combined oral contraceptives (COCs) containing estrogen and progestin are contraindicated in this patient, since estrogen may reduce breast milk production and enter the milk. Moreover, estrogen increases an already existing risk of venous thromboembolism (VTE) in the early postpartum period even further. COCs can be started safely after 4–6 weeks postpartum, when the VTE risk is declining to baseline, lactation is well established, and there is no longer a close relationship between the amount of prolactin and the amount of milk produced.

F) INCORRECT:

Breastfeeding causes lactational amenorrhea by suckling-induced disruption of GnRH and LH release, preventing ovulation, and is used as a contraceptive method by some women (lactational amenorrhea method). However, it is not completely reliable and the risk of pregnancy increases when the mother starts breastfeeding less often, uses supplement feeding, her period returns, or more than 6 months have passed since delivery. Some women may be fertile again as early as 3 weeks after delivery if they do not fully breastfeed.

G) INCORRECT:

Estrogen is contraindicated in breastfeeding women in the postpartum period because it may reduce breast milk production and enter the milk. Moreover, estrogen increases an already existing risk of venous thromboembolism (VTE) even further in the early postpartum period. An estrogen patch may be used safely after 3–6 weeks postpartum when the VTE risk has gone back to baseline, and lactation is well established. The patch is applied weekly for three consecutive weeks, followed by a patch-free week, improving the compliance compared to combined oral contraceptive pills that have to be taken daily.
questions.hint: It is important to consider this patient's history when evaluating the most appropriate contraceptive method.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. She had a spontaneous abortion 3 months ago. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. She reports feeling sad occasionally but has continued working and attending social events. She does not have any suicidal ideation or tendencies. She does not smoke. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination including pelvic examination shows no abnormalities. A urine pregnancy test is negative. She wants to avoid becoming pregnant for the foreseeable future and is started on combined oral contraceptive pills. Which of the following is the patient at risk of developing?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Certain progestin-only contraceptive pills may increase the incidence of ovarian cysts, but combined oral contraceptive therapy (estrogen-progestin combination) is not known to increase the incidence of functional ovarian cysts.

B) INCORRECT:

The use of high doses of certain progestin-only pills (e.g., levonorgestrel) may result in hyperandrogenism and acne. However, in combined oral contraceptive therapy (estrogen-progestin combination), any androgenic effect progestin may have is offset by the strong hypoandrogenic effect of the estrogenic component (typically ethinyl estradiol). Combined oral contraceptives are, in fact, used to treat severe inflammatory acne in females.

C) INCORRECT:

Prolonged estrogen stimulation of the endometrium that is unopposed by progesterone (e.g., postmenopausal patients receiving estrogen replacement therapy without progestin) would increase the risk of endometrial cancer. However, combined oral contraceptive therapy (estrogen-progestin combinations) actually decreases the risk of endometrial cancer.

D) INCORRECT:

Despite common belief, oral contraceptives are not known to cause weight gain.

E) INCORRECT:

Oral contraceptive therapy decreases, not increases, the risk of benign breast cysts.

F) INCORRECT:

Premenstrual syndrome (PMS) typically occurs in female individuals of reproductive age. Oral contraceptive use decreases, not increases, the incidence of PMS. Risk factors for PMS instead include obesity, anxiety, stress, and depression.

G) CORRECT:

The use of estrogen-containing oral contraceptives increases the risk of cardiovascular side effects such as hypertension and thromboembolism. Estrogen-containing oral contraceptives may also cause hyperlipidemia and a mild increase in the incidence of hepatic adenomas.

The most common adverse effect of oral contraceptives is breakthrough bleedings. Oral contraceptives are not known to cause weight gain or have any long-term effects on fertility.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman comes to the physician because of recent weight gain. She started a combined oral contraceptive for dysmenorrhea and acne six months ago. She has been taking the medication consistently and experiences withdrawal bleeding on the 4th week of each pill pack. Her acne and dysmenorrhea have improved significantly. The patient increased her daily exercise regimen to 60 minutes of running and weight training three months ago. She started college six months ago. She has not had any changes in her sleep or energy levels. She is 162 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 62 kg (137 lbs); six months ago she weighed 57 kg (126 lbs). Examination shows clear skin and no other abnormalities. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Perform a low-dose dexamethasone suppression test
Switch contraceptive to a nonhormonal contraceptive method
Switch contraceptive to a progestin-only pill

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This woman started gaining weight around the time she started treatment with combined oral contraceptives (COC) but, despite popular belief, weight gain has not been proven to be a side effect of COC. Since the patient also started college 6 months ago and has recently intensified her training routine, her weight gain is most likely attributable to changes in eating habits and an increase in muscle mass. As the current treatment has also proven to be beneficial for her previous dysmenorrhea and acne, reassurance and advice on maintaining a healthy weight are the most appropriate steps in management.

B) INCORRECT:

Serum thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) levels are measured to diagnose thyroid disorders, such as hypothyroidism. Individuals with hypothyroidism often present with symptoms of decreased metabolic rate, including fatigue, weight gain, cold intolerance, constipation, and secondary amenorrhea. In the absence of any other typical features of hypothyroidism, this woman's weight gain is more likely due to other causes.

C) INCORRECT:

Serum testosterone levels are measured in women with suspected polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), a disorder characterized by hyperandrogenism, anovulation, and polycystic ovaries. Typical clinical features include menstrual irregularities (e.g., amenorrhea), infertility, hirsutism, obesity, and acne. Although PCOS causes acne, and the condition may also improve with combined oral contraceptive treatment, she had no other features suggestive of PCOS and only started gaining weight after treatment, which makes this diagnosis unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

A low-dose dexamethasone suppression test is used to diagnose elevated cortisol levels in individuals with Cushing's syndrome. Common clinical features include hypertension, central obesity, moon facies, easily bruisable skin and acne, muscle atrophy, and features of virilization in women (hirsutism, menstrual cycle irregularities). Since this woman's weight gain did not occur simultaneously with her other symptoms and she does not have hypertension, Cushing's syndrome is unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

A pelvic ultrasound is performed to confirm pregnancy. Although weight gain is a symptom of pregnancy, pregnancy is unlikely since she consistently takes oral contraceptives, menstruates regularly, and her urine pregnancy test is negative.

F) INCORRECT:

Switching from hormonal contraceptive methods to nonhormonal contraceptive methods is indicated in women who experience side effects or have contraindications to combined hormonal contraception (e.g., development of hepatic adenoma, increased risk of thromboembolism, estrogen-dependent tumor). Since this woman's dysmenorrhea and acne have improved since starting treatment with combined oral contraceptives (COCs) and there is no evidence that weight gain is a side effect of COCs, there is no indication to change her treatment regimen.

G) INCORRECT:

Progestin-only contraceptive pills are indicated in women who have contraindications to treatment with estrogen-containing combined oral contraceptives. Contraindications include estrogen-dependent and hepatic tumors, an increased risk for thromboembolic events and cardiovascular disease, cigarette smoking, acute pancreatitis, and systemic lupus erythematosus. Since this patient has no known contraindications to estrogen-containing treatment and is tolerating her current medication well, a change in treatment is not indicated.
questions.hint: Consider the causes of this patient's weight gain.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She feels well. She lives with her parents at home. She says that the relationship with her parents has been strained lately because they "do not approve" of her new boyfriend. She recently became sexually active with her boyfriend and requests a prescription for oral contraception. She does not want her parents to know. She smokes one-half pack of cigarettes daily and does not drink alcohol. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Inform patient that her smoking history disqualifies her for combined oral contraceptives
Ask patient to obtain parental consent before discussing any contraceptive options

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Smoking, in general, is a relative contraindication to combined oral contraceptives (COC). It is only an absolute contraindication in patients older than 35 years, but this patient is only 16 years of age. She should be counseled regarding the risks associated with OCP use, specifically in relation to smoking; OCPs are still a viable option for her.

B) CORRECT:

Discussing all effective contraceptive options and providing the patient with unbiased and objective information should be the first step. Parental consent is not required for providing information (all states) to mature minors, nor for prescribing contraceptives (most states).

C) INCORRECT:

Parental consent is not required for providing information about contraceptive options in any state. In most states, parental consent is also not required for prescribing contraceptive drugs to mature minors.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral contraceptive pills are a very common and efficient contraceptive method. However, the patient needs to be informed about all contraceptive options so that both patient and doctor can decide on a suitable contraceptive method together.
questions.hint: As a physician, you should always try to respect privacy, be empathetic, and help in questions of health.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman comes to the physician because she had unprotected sexual intercourse with her boyfriend 2 days ago. She wants to avoid pregnancy in the next 6 months because she is finishing college but would like to conceive after she graduates. She has had regular menses since menarche at the age of 12 years. Menses occur at regular 28-day intervals, and her last menstrual period was 1 week ago. She has been taking doxycycline for cervicitis. She is 173 cm (5 ft 8 in) tall and weighs 59 kg (130 lb); BMI is 20 kg/m2. A urine pregnancy test is negative. She requests emergency contraception. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intrauterine devices (IUDs) are the most effective option for emergency contraception and have a success rate of > 99%. However, cervicitis is a contraindication for inserting an IUD. A different type of emergency contraception should be considered.

B) INCORRECT:

Intrauterine devices (IUDs) are the most effective option for emergency contraception and have a success rate of > 99%. However, cervicitis is a contraindication for inserting an IUD. A different type of emergency contraception should be considered.

C) INCORRECT:

Mifepristone is indicated for the medical abortion of an established pregnancy. Although mifepristone is used for emergency contraception in some countries, it is not currently approved for emergency contraception in the United States.

D) CORRECT:

For patients who request emergency contraception but who have contraindications for inserting an intrauterine device (IUD), either oral ulipristal acetate or oral levonorgestrel is an appropriate choice. Ulipristal acetate is up to 99% effective in preventing pregnancy if administered within five days of unprotected intercourse, and levonorgestrel is up to 98% effective if administered within three days of unprotected intercourse. These oral emergency contraceptives are most effective during the first half of the menstrual cycle (i.e., before ovulation) and in patients with a healthy weight.

Copper and levonorgestrel IUDs are more effective than oral ulipristal or oral levonorgestrel for emergency contraception, but they are not appropriate for patients with contraindications: endometrial or cervical precancerous lesions or cancer; symptomatic STIs within the last three months; and, in the case of copper IUDs, Wilson disease or a history suggestive of copper allergy.

E) INCORRECT:

Depot medroxyprogesterone acetate (DMPA) is widely used for long-term contraception, particularly in individuals who do not want to take a daily contraceptive, as it is only administered once every three months. DMPA is not used for emergency contraception.

F) INCORRECT:

Combined oral contraceptive pills are widely used for long-term contraception. They can also be used as a Yuzpe regimen for emergency contraception but are the least effective option for this indication (approx. 3–4% failure rate).
questions.hint: This option is not appropriate for patients taking certain cytochrome p450 inducers, such as rifampicin or carbamazepine, because of the risk of emergency contraception failure.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman comes to the physician for evaluation of worsening pain, swelling, and erythema in her left leg for the past 4 hours. She returned from a trip to Taiwan to celebrate her sister's wedding 2 days ago. She has no history of serious illness. She is sexually active with one male partner and uses a combined oral contraceptive pill. She does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. Her only other medication is a multivitamin. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 67/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Examination shows swelling in her left calf and pain behind her left knee when she is asked to dorsiflex her left foot. Laboratory results show elevated D-dimer. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Increased protein C levels would lead to a decreased clotting risk, due to inactivation of procoagulation factors Va and VIIIa. However, this patient shows an increased clotting risk, which makes another underlying cause more likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Decreased levels of the prothrombotic factor VII would reduce the likelihood of thrombus formation. However, estrogen found within COCs increases, rather than decreases, the synthesis of factor VII (in addition to factors II, VIII, and X), which increases the risk for DVT.

C) INCORRECT:

Decreased levels of fibrinogen reduce the likelihood of thrombus formation since fibrinogen helps promote clot formation. However, estrogen found within COCs increases, rather than decreases, fibrinogen hepatic synthesis, which contributes to the increased risk for DVT. This patient has no risk factors for decreased fibrinogen levels, such as decreased hepatic synthesis capacity (e.g., liver cirrhosis) or disseminated intravascular coagulation (due to widespread thrombi formation).

D) INCORRECT:

ADAMTS13 deficiency causes thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP), which is characterized by microthrombus formation within small vessels, resulting in low platelet counts. Thrombi in bigger vessels that result in DVT are not commonly seen in TTP. Instead, patients with TTP present with fever, neurological signs, impaired renal function, hemolytic anemia as well as bleeding of the mucosa and skin. Furthermore, COCs are not known to affect ADAMTS13 levels.

E) INCORRECT:

Vitamin K is required for the synthesis of various coagulation factors (II, VII, IX, and X) and anticoagulation factors (protein C and protein S). Although vitamin K deficiency increases bleeding risks, vitamin K supplementation via a multivitamin would not significantly increase thrombosis risk. COCs do not affect vitamin K levels.

F) CORRECT:

Estrogen found within COCs decreases protein S levels. Since protein S is an essential cofactor for protein C, which inactivates procoagulant factors Va and VIIIa, reduction of protein S results in an increased risk for thrombus formation and the development of DVTs.
Image Description:

Clotting homeostasis is maintained through a balance of procoagulation (purple) and anticoagulation (gray) processes. The procoagulation pathway ultimately results in the enzymatic conversion of fibrinogen into fibrin, which is an integral part of blood clot formation. The procoagulation pathway is physiologically inhibited through two distinct anticoagulation pathways, using either antithrombin III or the APC complex.

Antithrombin III inactivates factors IX, X, and thrombin. This process is accelerated in the presence of heparin. Additionally, antithrombin III indirectly increases the activation of plasmin through the action of tissue plasminogen activator (tPA), resulting in the degradation of both fibrinogen and fibrin.

The APC complex pathway involves the activity of thrombomodulin, a membrane protein expressed on endothelial cells that activates protein C. Activated protein C then binds to protein S to form the APC complex, which inactivates procoagulation factors V and VIII. The procoagulation factor thrombin can also activate protein C, which results in a negative feedback loop on the procoagulation pathway.
questions.hint: This patient's combined oral contraceptive (COC) use and recent period of immobilization on her international plane flight place her at increased risk for the development of deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which is consistent with her clinical findings and positive D-dimer.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She recently became sexually active with her boyfriend and requests a prescription for an oral contraception. She lives with her parents. She has smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 2 years. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate response?

choices.text: "I would recommend performing a Pap smear, since you have become sexually active."
"I would like to discuss the various contraceptive options that are available."
"I would need your parent's permission before I can provide information about contraceptive therapy."
"I cannot prescribe oral contraceptives if you are currently a smoker."
"I would recommend a multiphasic combination of ethinyl estradiol and norgestimate."

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The USPSTF and ACOG recommend annual screening for chlamydia and gonorrhea in sexually active teens, but a Pap smear is not required until the age of 21 years, even if the patient is sexually active.

B) CORRECT:

Discussing the different contraceptive options and providing the patient with unbiased and objective information should be the first step. Parental consent is not required for providing information to mature minors (in any state), nor for prescribing contraceptives (in most states).

C) INCORRECT:

Parental consent is not required in order to provide a minor with information about contraceptive options in any state. In most states, parental consent is also not required for prescribing contraceptive drugs to minors between the ages of 14 and 17 years.

D) INCORRECT:

Smoking, in general, is a relative contraindication to oral contraceptives (OCP). It is only an absolute contraindication in patients older than 35 years, but this patient is only 15. While she should be counseled regarding the risks associated with OCP use, specifically in relation to smoking, OCPs are still a viable option for her.

E) INCORRECT:

Combined oral contraceptive therapy is a very effective and commonly used contraceptive method. However, the patient should be informed about all contraceptive options so that both patient and doctor can decide on a suitable contraceptive method together.
questions.hint: As a physician, you should always try to respect privacy, be empathetic, and offer appropriate counseling.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman comes to the physician to discuss the prescription of an oral contraceptive. She has no history of major medical illness and takes no medications. She does not smoke cigarettes. She is sexually active with her boyfriend and has been using condoms for contraception. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. She is prescribed combined levonorgestrel and ethinylestradiol tablets. Which of the following is the most important mechanism of action of this drug in the prevention of pregnancy?

choices.text: Inhibition of rise in luteinizing hormone

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Combined oral contraceptives, primarily through progestin, decrease the volume and increase the viscosity of cervical mucus. While this renders the cervix less permeable to sperm and aids in preventing pregnancy, it is not the most important contraceptive mechanism of these drugs.

B) CORRECT:

The most important mechanism of action of combined oral contraceptives in preventing ovulation is the inhibition of the LH surge. The estrogen and progestin in combined OCPs provide negative feedback to the hypothalamus, preventing the release of GnRH and, subsequently, both FSH and LH. This decreased gonadotropin secretion prevents the spike in estrogen (released from the Graafian follicle) necessary to induce the LH surge in the pituitary, which then initiates ovulation. This significantly reduces the possibility of successful fertilization (< 1% with perfect use; 9% with typical use).

OCPs are contraindicated in women who have migraines with aura, smoke cigarettes above the age of 35 years, or have a history of stroke, thromboembolism, breast cancer, or liver disease.
Image Description:

The menstrual cycle consists of two phases: the follicular and the luteal phase. The onset of menses marks the beginning of the follicular phase, which usually lasts 12–14 days but may be variable. The luteal phase begins on the day of ovulation and lasts 14 days.

During the follicular phase, FSH and LH stimulate the development of several follicles, one of which develops as the dominant follicle into the Graafian follicle. An LH surge initiates ovulation. As the oocyte reaches the fallopian tube, the ruptured follicle transforms into the corpus luteum, which produces progesterone. If no pregnancy occurs, the corpus luteum regresses and the progesterone level drops. This drop induces vasospasms in the uterine spiral arteries, ischemia, and sloughing off of the functional endometrial layer, which leads to menstrual bleeding (menstrual phase). During the proliferative phase, the endometrium is built up again in preparation for oocyte implantation during the secretory phase.

1: stages of follicle development; 2: hormone levels; 3: phases of the endometrial cycle; 4: development of the endometrium during the cycle

C) INCORRECT:

Combined OCPs can reduce folliculogenesis, both through the estrogen-mediated decrease in circulating FSH and through the progestin-mediated inhibition of follicle maturation. However, women taking combined pills with low doses of ethinylestradiol can still develop follicles. This is not the main contraceptive mechanism of this drug.

D) INCORRECT:

Combined oral contraceptives increase the amount of sex-hormone binding globulin, but this does not contribute to their contraceptive mechanisms. This effect is particularly useful in patients with hyperandrogenism (e.g., PCOS) as it decreases the levels of free androgen in the blood and reduces the symptoms of acne and hirsutism.

E) INCORRECT:

The progestin in combined oral contraceptives acts on the uterus by inhibiting endometrial proliferation, which creates a less suitable environment for implantation of a fertilized zygote. However, this is considered a minor contraceptive effect.
questions.hint: Combined oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) deliver a constant, low dose of estrogen and progesterone.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman comes to the physician because of bothersome hair growth on her face and abdomen over the past 8 years. She does not take any medications. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 85 kg (187 lb); BMI is 32 kg/m2. Physical examination shows coarse dark hair on the upper lip and periumbilical and periareolar skin. Her external genitalia appear normal. Her serum follicle-stimulating hormone, luteinizing hormone, and testosterone are within the reference range. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy at this time?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Flutamide may be used in the management of IH. However, it is not the first-line therapy in the treatment of hirsutism but rather a third-line antiandrogen considered only for patients who have been refractory to at least 6 months of monotherapy with another medication. Spironolactone is considered the first-line antiandrogen used in patients with refractory moderate to severe hirsutism, with finasteride and cyproterone acetate being the second-line antiandrogens.

B) INCORRECT:

Leuprolide, a gonadotropin-releasing hormone receptor agonist (GnRH agonist), inhibits ovarian androgen secretion and can therefore suppress male pattern hair growth. However, this therapy is not considered first-line management of IH and has a risk of estrogen deficiency.

C) INCORRECT:

Ketoconazole has been used to treat hirsutism in patients with PCOS as it attenuates serum androgen levels at low doses. It also inhibits ovarian steroidogenesis in vitro. However, ketoconazole is not the first-line therapy in treating patients with IH.

D) CORRECT:

Combined oral contraceptives are recommended as the first-line therapy for women with hirsutism due to their ability to reduce androgen levels. Estrogen-progestin contraceptives reduce androgen levels by suppression of circulating luteinizing hormone (LH) and stimulation of sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG) levels.

E) INCORRECT:

Metformin is used in the management of polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) to reduce circulating insulin levels. While effective in PCOS, metformin is not effective in treating patients with IH.
questions.hint: This woman presents with slow progression of excessive male pattern hair growth (hirsutism) with normal gonadotropins and testosterone levels without signs of further virilization. This combination is highly suggestive of idiopathic hirsutism (IH).

questions.text: A 45-year-old man undergoes elective vasectomy for permanent contraception. The procedure is performed under local anesthesia. There are no intraoperative complications and he is discharged home with ibuprofen for postoperative pain. Which of the following conditions should the patient be counseled on the risk of developing over the next 3 months?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Because there can still be motile, viable sperm in the vas deferens lumen distal to the site of occlusion, patients undergoing vasectomy are advised to use an alternative method of contraception during the first 3 months after the procedure to avoid an unplanned pregnancy. Three months post-vasectomy, a follow-up examination is conducted to test semen samples for azoospermia to determine the success of the procedure before ceasing to use alternative methods of contraception. Patients should also be counseled about the small risk of post-vasectomy pregnancy (approximately 1 in 2000 cases) due to recanalization.

Other complications of a vasectomy include surgical site infection, sperm granulomas, post-vasectomy pain syndrome, hematomas, and failure of the procedure (persistence of sperm in the ejaculate).

B) INCORRECT:

Seminomas are true germ cell tumors and the most common testicular tumor. They are associated with painless testicular enlargement, late metastasis, and an excellent prognosis. Risk factors include undescended testis, a previous tumor of the contralateral testis, and a family history of testicular cancer, but not vasectomy.

C) INCORRECT:

Risk factors for testicular torsion include inadequate fixation of the testicle's lower pole to the tunica vaginalis (congenital “bell clapper” deformity), enlargement of the testes (e.g., testicular tumor), and acute groin injury. A vasectomy involves very small incisions in the scrotal skin to localize the vas deferens; such incisions do not predispose patients to testicular torsion.

D) INCORRECT:

Inguinal hernias are abnormal protrusions of intra-abdominal contents either through the deep inguinal ring (indirect inguinal hernia) or through the weakened posterior wall of the inguinal canal (direct inguinal hernia). Risk factors include old age, chronic cough, chronic constipation, and abdominal surgery. A vasectomy involves very small incisions in the scrotal skin to localize the vas deferens; such incisions do not predispose patients to inguinal hernias.

E) INCORRECT:

Prostatitis is caused primarily by infections of urogenital origin. Catheter-associated urinary tract infections are a surgery-associated risk for prostatitis due to impeded urinary flow. However, vasectomies are performed under local anesthesia and do not require patient catheterization.
questions.hint: Vasectomies are surgical procedures that divide and occlude the vas deferens. The entire procedure takes approximately 15 minutes.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl comes to the physician because of an 8-month history of severe acne vulgaris over her face, upper back, arms, and buttocks. Treatment with oral antibiotics and topical combination therapy with benzoyl peroxide and retinoid has not completely resolved her symptoms. Examination shows oily skin with numerous comedones, pustules, and scarring over the face and upper back. Long-term therapy is started with combined oral contraceptive pills. These pills decrease the patient's risk of developing which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Combined oral contraceptives increase the risk for hypertension, although this risk minimizes shortly after drug cessation. The mechanism of oral contraception-induced hypertension is not clear but may be related to elevated angiotensinogen levels.

B) CORRECT:

For patients with continued severe acne vulgaris despite first-line therapies (e.g., oral antibiotics and topical combination therapy), COCP can be added. COCPs can decrease the risk of ovarian cancer, possibly through reduced cell proliferation within the ovaries and fallopian tubes. They also reduce the risk of endometrial cancer; the progestin contained therein opposes estrogen-driven endometrial hyperplasia, which reduces the risk for the development of type 1 endometrial cancer.

C) INCORRECT:

Combined oral contraceptives do not have a known effect on skin cancer risks.

D) INCORRECT:

Long-term combined oral contraceptive use (≥ 5 years) is associated with an increased risk of cervical cancer. This association is likely based upon how OCPs affect the response of cervical cells to an HPV infection, the main cause of cervical cancer, by increasing susceptibility to infection and/or decreasing the ability to clear it.

E) INCORRECT:

Combined oral contraceptives are associated with an increased risk for deep vein thrombosis because estrogen induces transcription of clotting factors (II, VII, VIII, X, XII) and fibrinogen to promote clot formation.

F) INCORRECT:

Combined oral contraceptives increase the risk for a hepatic adenoma. Although the mechanism is not fully clear, it may be related to estrogen-induced vascular dilation.

G) INCORRECT:

Combined oral contraceptives do not reduce the risk for breast cancer. However, there is controversy as to whether current OCPs actually increase the risk for breast cancer, and therefore should be used with caution in a patient with a high risk for breast cancer development (e.g., BRCA mutations).
questions.hint: An inhibition of cell proliferation also decreases the chance for cancer cells to arise.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 3, comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. She gave birth to her third child 8 months ago and now wishes to start a contraception method. Prior to her most recent pregnancy, she used a combined estrogen-progestin pill. Which of the following aspects of her history would be a contraindication for restarting an oral contraceptive pill?

choices.text: She smokes 1 pack of cigarettes daily
She has recurrent migraine headaches without aura
She has a history of cervical dysplasia
Her father had an ischemic stroke

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A hemoglobin A1c level of 8.6% indicates diabetes mellitus. Insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus with vascular injury manifesting with end-organ damage (e.g., nephropathy, retinopathy, or neuropathy) is an absolute contraindication for OCP. However, there is no evidence of end-organ damage in this patient, so OCPs are not contraindicated.

B) CORRECT:

Oral contraceptives (OCPs) are contraindicated in individuals ≥ 35 years of age who smoke ≥ 15 cigarettes a day. Combined estrogen-progestin OCPs increase the risk of venous thromboembolism (VTE), predominantly because estrogen induces a prothrombotic state. Because smoking has a similar prothrombotic effect, OCPs are contraindicated in heavy smokers to prevent VTE.

Further contraindications for OCP use include severe hypertension, ischemic heart disease, complicated valvular disease, known coagulopathy, breast cancer, and cirrhosis.

C) INCORRECT:

While migraine headaches with aura are absolute contraindications for OCP use, in the absence of an aura OCP use is not contraindicated.

D) INCORRECT:

Large-scale prospective studies have found that long-term OCP use is associated with only a slight increase in the risk of cervical cancer and that the risk returns to normal after OCP cessation. Cervical dysplasia is not an absolute contraindication for OCP use.

E) INCORRECT:

While a medical history of cerebrovascular accident in the patient herself would be an absolute contraindication for OCP use, a family history of stroke does not contraindicate the initiation of contraception.

F) INCORRECT:

In the immediate post-partum period (30 days after delivery), combined estrogen-progestin OCP use is absolutely contraindicated in patients breastfeeding their infants. However, this patient is 8 months post-partum, at which point combined OCP use is appropriate.
questions.hint: Among other adverse effects, oral contraceptive pills increase the risk of deep vein thrombosis.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman comes to the physician for contraceptive counseling. She has recently become sexually active with her boyfriend and expresses concerns because approximately 10 days ago the condom broke during intercourse. Her medical history is significant for deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism. Urine pregnancy test is negative. After discussing different contraceptive options, the patient says, “I'd like to try the most effective method that works without hormones and would allow me to become pregnant at a later time.” The contraceptive method that best meets the patient's wishes has which of the following mechanisms?

choices.text: Preventing passage of semen into the cervix

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fertility awareness-based methods such as abstinence during the fertile period are nonhormonal, side-effect free, and inexpensive. Methods for estimating the fertile period are the calendar method, the cervical mucus method, the basal body temperature method, and the symptothermal method. However, all of these methods are inexact and prone to human error, resulting in a high failure rate. There is a more effective method of contraception that meets this patient's wishes.

B) CORRECT:

Nonhormonal intrauterine devices (IUDs) release copper into the uterine cavity, which induces sterile inflammation of the endometrium. This local inflammatory reaction has spermicidal effects and prevents fertilization. The failure rate of IUDs is around 0.5%, making them one of the most effective contraceptives. Copper IUDs are long-acting reversible contraceptives, and pregnancy is possible after removal. Side effects include increased or irregular menstrual bleeding, dysmenorrhea, ectopic pregnancy, and pelvic inflammatory disease.

The copper IUD is the most effective type of emergency contraception and can be placed up to 5 days post-intercourse.

C) INCORRECT:

Barrier contraceptive methods (e.g., condom, diaphragm, cervical cap, sponge) prevent the passage of semen into the cervix and are nonhormonal contraceptives that can be considered in young women with a history of thrombosis. However, failure rates range from 12–14% and this patient has already been using condoms. There is a more effective method of contraception that meets this patient's wishes.

D) INCORRECT:

Ligation of the fallopian tubes is a nonreversible surgical method of female sterilization. Although this patient's history of thrombosis is not a contraindication and failure rate is only 0.5%, irreversible sterilization would not be the method of choice for a young woman who wants to have children at a later point in life.

E) INCORRECT:

Thickening of cervical mucus impairs sperm ascension and is an effect of both progestin-only oral contraceptives (also known as “minipill”) and hormonal intrauterine devices (IUDs). Although neither progestin-only pills nor hormonal IUDs are contraindicated in patients with a history of thrombosis, this patient has explicitly requested a nonhormonal contraceptive method. Additionally, the pregnancy rate in the first year with typical use of the minipill is relatively high (∼ 9%). There is a more effective method of contraception that meets this patient's wishes.

F) INCORRECT:

Prevention of ovulation by inhibiting the release of luteinizing hormone and follicle-stimulating hormone is the mechanism of action of combined (estrogen-progestin) hormonal contraceptives (e.g., combined oral contraceptive, contraceptive patch, vaginal ring). This patient has a history of thrombosis, which is an absolute contraindication for estrogen-containing contraceptives. Progestin-only contraceptives (“minipill”) prevent ovulation in ∼ 60% of cases and are not contraindicated in this patient. However, she has explicitly requested a nonhormonal contraceptive method. Finally, the pregnancy rate in the first year with typical use of both combined and progestin-only contraceptives is relatively high (∼ 9%). There is a more effective method of contraception that meets this patient's wishes.
questions.hint: For a young patient with a history of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism and preference for nonhormonal methods, a reversible contraceptive method such as the copper intrauterine device is most appropriate.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman comes to the physician because of bilateral breast pain for the past 4 months. The symptom started after she began taking oral contraceptives prescribed by the physician. She appears upset and says, “This is ridiculous! Ever since you prescribed me these pills, my breasts hurt almost every day and it is taking a toll on my relationship; my boyfriend can't even get near me.” She has no family history of breast cancer. Breast examination shows mild bilateral diffuse tenderness and no masses. There is no redness, swelling, or warmth of the breasts. The physician apologizes for her pain and explains the risks and benefits of alternative methods of contraception. When the physician suggests a copper intrauterine device, the patient seems unsure. The patient says she does not want to use nonhormonal alternatives because they are too unsafe. Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the physician?

choices.text: "Your symptoms are unlikely to be related to the oral contraceptive pill."
"Most of my patients in situations like yours have been very happy using this contraceptive method."
"Can you explain to me your understanding of how a copper intrauterine device works?"
"I really recommend trying a nonhormonal contraceptive. They are also very safe if used correctly."
"You seem unsure about the options presented. Would you like me to give you my personal opinion to help you with this decision?"

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This statement is incorrect. Breast pain is a common side effect of oral contraceptive pills. Moreover, the patient's opinion should be acknowledged.

B) INCORRECT:

Disclosure of other patients' experiences with a specific medication can influence a patient's decision. In this case, the patient's uncertainties about nonhormonal contraceptives were not acknowledged by the physician. Instead of mentioning other patients' experiences, the physician should provide neutral information to empower the patient in the shared decision-making process.

C) CORRECT:

Enabling a shared decision-making process by ensuring that a patient understands a treatment or procedure is a key principle in patient-physician communication. A useful way to uncover possible misunderstandings is by asking the patient for his or her own perspective on a medication or procedure. Other features of shared decision-making include ensuring the patient knows his or her options, providing relevant facts, and encouraging the patient to discuss his or her thoughts about the options.

D) INCORRECT:

Breast pain is a common side effect of hormonal contraceptives and would likely resolve if the patient switched to a nonhormonal contraceptive. However, this patient explicitly stated that she is worried about the safety of nonhormonal contraceptives. The patient's preferences should not be dismissed; more information should be provided about the safety of nonhormonal contraceptives.

E) INCORRECT:

Reflecting the patient's feelings to demonstrate listening and understanding is a good method of strengthening the patient-physician relationship. However, in a shared decision-making process, the physician should be as objective as possible and provide neutral information about the different options rather than offer personal opinions.
questions.hint: When counseling on contraception, it is important to explore the patient's preferences and concerns about the different available methods.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman comes to the physician requesting advice regarding contraception. She previously used condoms but stopped using them a few weeks ago after a condom broke during intercourse. Today, she is interested in other contraceptive options and has asked for a “more reliable and uncomplicated contraceptive method.” She was diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis 2 years ago. Her menses occur at regular 30-day intervals with normal flow. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable and she takes no medications. She does not smoke cigarettes. She is sexually active with one male partner and uses condoms inconsistently. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows no abnormalities. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation regarding contraception for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A contraceptive patch is an estrogen- and progestin-containing transdermal patch and is contraindicated in patients with a history of deep vein thrombosis. Furthermore, a contraceptive patch needs to be replaced weekly. This patient has asked for an uncomplicated contraceptive method and may benefit from a more long-term option.

B) INCORRECT:

Spermicidal foam can be used in patients with contraindications for estrogen-containing contraceptive methods. However, spermicidal foam is less effective when used as the sole contraceptive method rather than in combination with other contraception, and it must be applied before each instance of intercourse. Therefore, it is not the most appropriate choice for this patient who would like a reliable and uncomplicated contraceptive.

C) INCORRECT:

A vaginal ring is a hormonal contraceptive containing estrogen and progestin and is contraindicated in patients with a history of deep vein thrombosis. In addition, a vaginal ring needs to be removed every 3 weeks for 1 week. This patient has asked for an uncomplicated contraceptive method and may benefit from a more long-term option.

D) INCORRECT:

Combined oral contraceptive pills (COCP) contain estrogen, which can promote clot formation, and are, therefore, contraindicated in this patient with a history of deep vein thrombosis. In addition, COCPs need to be taken regularly. This patient has asked for an uncomplicated contraceptive method and may benefit from a more long-term option.

E) INCORRECT:

Fertility awareness-based methods can be used in patients with contraindications for estrogen-containing contraceptive methods, such as deep vein thrombosis, which is seen here. However, fertility awareness-based methods have a high risk of pregnancy and require monitoring throughout the menstrual cycle. Therefore, these methods are less appropriate for this patient, who would like a reliable and uncomplicated contraceptive.

F) CORRECT:

A copper intrauterine device (IUD) is an appropriate contraceptive option for patients with contraindications for estrogen-based contraceptives. Besides a history of thromboembolism (e.g., deep vein thrombosis), contraindications for these hormonal contraceptives include pregnancy, lactation, hypertension (systolic ≥ 160 mm Hg or diastolic ≥ 100 mm Hg), migraine with aura, hepatic dysfunction (e.g., due to cirrhosis), hepatic neoplasm, breast cancer, estrogen-dependent neoplasms, and smoking in individuals > 35 years of age. Patients with any of these contraindications may use nonhormonal contraceptives (e.g., copper IUDs, barrier contraception), as well as progestin-only hormonal contraceptives (e.g., minipill, subdermal progestin implant, progestin IUD). This patient, who would like a reliable and uncomplicated contraceptive, may benefit most from a copper IUD, which is a highly effective, long-acting reversible contraceptive.

Contraindications for a copper IUD include known or suspected pregnancy, menorrhagia, or dysmenorrhea, none of which are seen in this patient.
questions.hint: Estrogen induces transcription of clotting factors (II, VII, VIII, X, XII) and fibrinogen, and decreases antithrombin and protein S levels, all of which can promote clot formation.

questions.text: A healthy 26-year-old woman comes to the clinic requesting advice regarding contraception. Menses occur at 28-day intervals with moderate flow. She is sexually active with her husband and has been using a nonhormonal contraception method based on her body temperature. She avoids unprotected sexual intercourse from the start of menstruation until 3 days after a spike in her body temperature. She takes no medications. Examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's increase in body temperature?

choices.text: Release of progesterone by granulosa lutein cells
Increase in follicle-stimulating hormone serum concentration
Production of estrogen by follicular cells

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The release of progesterone by granulosa lutein cells (corpus luteum) results in an increase in the basal body temperature (BBT) by approximately 0.2–0.5°C. This occurs 1–2 days after the luteinizing hormone surge that induces ovulation and marks the transition from the follicular to the luteal phase of the menstrual cycle. Body temperature remains elevated for at least 10 days until the end of the cycle (i.e., the first day of menses).

The effectiveness of the basal body temperature method is dependent on regular menstrual cycles (6 menstrual cycles should be observed). Patients should use barrier protection or abstain from unprotected sexual intercourse from the beginning of the menstrual cycle until 3 days after the increase in basal body temperature. The peak fertile period usually occurs 1–2 days prior to the BBT increase (or when ovulation is most likely to occur), but it can extend for an additional 3 days after the BBT increase.
Image Description:

The menstrual cycle consists of two phases: the follicular and the luteal phase. The onset of menses marks the beginning of the follicular phase, which usually lasts 12–14 days but may be variable. The luteal phase begins on the day of ovulation and lasts 14 days.

During the follicular phase, FSH and LH stimulate the development of several follicles, one of which develops as the dominant follicle into the Graafian follicle. An LH surge initiates ovulation. As the oocyte reaches the fallopian tube, the ruptured follicle transforms into the corpus luteum, which produces progesterone. If no pregnancy occurs, the corpus luteum regresses and the progesterone level drops. This drop induces vasospasms in the uterine spiral arteries, ischemia, and sloughing off of the functional endometrial layer, which leads to menstrual bleeding (menstrual phase). During the proliferative phase, the endometrium is built up again in preparation for oocyte implantation during the secretory phase.

1: stages of follicle development; 2: hormone levels; 3: phases of the endometrial cycle; 4: development of the endometrium during the cycle

B) INCORRECT:

Follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) stimulates estradiol production from granulosa cells and recruits a group of maturing follicles during the follicular phase of the menstrual cycle. The basal body temperature increases after ovulation and remains elevated during the luteal phase, but this increase is not caused by FSH.

C) INCORRECT:

Estrogen is produced by follicular (granulosa) cells during the luteal phase. It promotes the proliferation and maturation of the endometrium. Although the basal body temperature remains elevated during the luteal phase until the end of the menstrual cycle, estrogen is not the cause of this increase.

D) INCORRECT:

The luteinizing hormone surge results from increasing estradiol concentrations (produced by granulosa cells during the follicular phase) and induces ovulation. The basal body temperature increases 1–2 days after ovulation and remains elevated throughout the luteal phase until the beginning of menses.
questions.hint: The hormone responsible for the rise in basal body temperature is produced in the adrenal cortex, corpus luteum, and testes.

Abdominal: nondistended; normoactive bowel sounds; soft, nontender

Which of the following is the most appropriate contraception method for this individual?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A subcutaneous levonorgestrel implant is a highly effective, reversible type of progestin-only hormonal contraception. The device is inserted subdermally in the upper arm and contains an extended-release form of levonorgestrel. However, levonorgestrel is contraindicated in patients with breast cancer or a recent history of breast cancer, as the stimulatory effects of exogenous hormones can increase the risk of cancer growth and recurrence.

B) INCORRECT:

Progestin-only oral contraceptive pills provide effective, short-acting, reversible contraception. However, progestins are contraindicated in patients with breast cancer or a recent history of breast cancer, as the stimulatory effects of exogenous hormones can increase the risk of cancer growth and recurrence.

C) INCORRECT:

Combined hormonal contraceptive pills provide highly effective, short-acting, reversible contraception. However, they contain estrogen and progestins, which are both contraindicated in patients with breast cancer or a recent history of breast cancer, as the stimulatory effects of exogenous hormones can increase the risk of cancer growth and recurrence.

D) CORRECT:

A copper intrauterine device is a hormone-free, long-lasting, reliable, and reversible method of contraception. All hormone-based contraception is contraindicated in individuals with a recent history (≤ 5 years) of breast cancer, irrespective of hormone receptor status, as the stimulatory effects of exogenous hormones can increase the risk of recurrence.

E) INCORRECT:

An intramuscular medroxyprogesterone acetate depot is a highly effective, reversible form of progestin-only hormonal contraception that is administered by injection every 3 months. However, medroxyprogesterone acetate is contraindicated in patients with breast cancer or a recent history of breast cancer, as the stimulatory effects of exogenous hormones can increase the risk of cancer growth and recurrence.
questions.hint: This individual's history of breast cancer should be taken into account when choosing a method of contraception.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old woman with a history of obesity, hypothyroidism, and gestational diabetes requests a prescription for contraceptives. She had gestational hypertension during her only pregnancy 3 years ago, but since then, her blood pressure and glycated hemoglobin level have remained normal. She does not want an intrauterine device.
Her only current medication is levothyroxine 125 μg daily by mouth. She has no family history of pulmonary embolism, deep-vein thrombosis, or stroke. Her father has a history of type 2 diabetes, and her mother and maternal aunt have had hypothyroidism and pancreatitis attributed to severe hypertriglyceridemia.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Total cholesterol (mg/dL)
328
125–200


LDL cholesterol (mg/dL)
112
<130


HDL cholesterol (mg/dL)
48
≥46


Triglycerides (mg/dL)
840
<150


Glycated hemoglobin (%)
5.3
4.3–5.6


Thyroid-stimulating hormone (μU/mL)
2.1
0.5–4.7


Which one of the following hormonal contraceptives is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Administration of systemic estrogen can raise plasma triglyceride concentrations by as much as 25%. Although screening for lipid abnormalities before initiation of oral contraceptive pills is not recommended given the low prevalence of dyslipidemia, this patient already has known, severe hypertriglyceridemia. In patients with milder triglyceride elevations, estrogen-containing contraceptives can be prescribed with monitoring of triglyceride levels; transdermal or vaginal formulations may be particularly attractive given the smaller triglyceride elevations with nonoral routes of administration. However, in this patient, starting an estrogen-containing product would likely lead to a triglyceride level above 1000 mg/dL, which would put her at risk for acute pancreatitis. All of the listed estrogen-containing contraceptives are therefore best avoided in this patient.

B) CORRECT:

Given this patient’s severe hypertriglyceridemia, the most appropriate hormonal contraceptive for her is one that contains progestin only, such as depot medroxyprogesterone acetate, a levonorgestrel-releasing intrauterine device (IUD), or an etonogestrel implant. A nonhormonal long-acting reversible contraceptive, such as the copper IUD, would also be an excellent option for this patient, but she does not want an IUD.

Use of depot medroxyprogesterone acetate has been associated with a transient decrease in HDL cholesterol and an increase in LDL cholesterol, with no effect on triglycerides. Although weight gain is a known side effect of depot medroxyprogesterone acetate, the magnitude of the weight gain is modest (generally less than 2 kg).

Administration of systemic estrogen can raise plasma triglyceride concentrations by as much as 25%. Although screening for lipid abnormalities before initiation of oral contraceptive pills is not recommended given the low prevalence of dyslipidemia, this patient already has known, severe hypertriglyceridemia. In patients with milder triglyceride elevations, estrogen-containing contraceptives can be prescribed with monitoring of triglyceride levels; transdermal or vaginal formulations may be particularly attractive given the smaller triglyceride elevations with nonoral routes of administration. However, in this patient, starting an estrogen-containing product would likely lead to a triglyceride level above 1000 mg/dL, which would put her at risk for acute pancreatitis. All of the listed estrogen-containing contraceptives are therefore best avoided in this patient.

Estrogen-containing contraceptives are also contraindicated in patients with uncontrolled hypertension; tobacco use (if age >35 years); a history of deep-vein thrombosis, stroke, or known thrombogenic mutations; migraine with aura; cirrhosis; hepatocellular adenoma; multiple risk factors for cardiovascular disease such as diabetes mellitus for >20 years or complicated by retinopathy, nephropathy, or neuropathy; use of certain anticonvulsant medications; breast cancer; or a history of surgery leading to prolonged immobilization.

Key learning point: For a woman with severe hypertriglyceridemia who does not want an intrauterine device, the most appropriate hormonal contraceptive is one that contains progestin only, such as depot medroxyprogesterone acetate.

C) INCORRECT:

Administration of systemic estrogen can raise plasma triglyceride concentrations by as much as 25%. Although screening for lipid abnormalities before initiation of oral contraceptive pills is not recommended given the low prevalence of dyslipidemia, this patient already has known, severe hypertriglyceridemia. In patients with milder triglyceride elevations, estrogen-containing contraceptives can be prescribed with monitoring of triglyceride levels; transdermal or vaginal formulations may be particularly attractive given the smaller triglyceride elevations with nonoral routes of administration. However, in this patient, starting an estrogen-containing product would likely lead to a triglyceride level above 1000 mg/dL, which would put her at risk for acute pancreatitis. All of the listed estrogen-containing contraceptives are therefore best avoided in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Administration of systemic estrogen can raise plasma triglyceride concentrations by as much as 25%. Although screening for lipid abnormalities before initiation of oral contraceptive pills is not recommended given the low prevalence of dyslipidemia, this patient already has known, severe hypertriglyceridemia. In patients with milder triglyceride elevations, estrogen-containing contraceptives can be prescribed with monitoring of triglyceride levels; transdermal or vaginal formulations may be particularly attractive given the smaller triglyceride elevations with nonoral routes of administration. However, in this patient, starting an estrogen-containing product would likely lead to a triglyceride level above 1000 mg/dL, which would put her at risk for acute pancreatitis. All of the listed estrogen-containing contraceptives are therefore best avoided in this patient.
