All of the listed estrogen-containing contraceptives are therefore best avoided in this patient.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old nulliparous woman presents to discuss contraception. Her gynecologic history includes abnormal results on a Pap test several years ago, but a repeat Pap test was normal. She has hypertension, for which she takes a low-dose angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitor. She smokes approximately five cigarettes daily and is trying to quit. Her mother was diagnosed with breast cancer at age 54.
On physical examination, her heart rate is 93 beats per minute and her blood pressure is 165/99 mm Hg. Her BMI is 35.5.
Which one of the following contraceptives is the safest, most effective choice for this patient while she continues to receive antihypertensive treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Progestin-only contraceptive pills, spermicides, and intrauterine devices (both copper-containing and progesterone-based) are all safe for women with hypertension. However, the failure rates associated with typical use of progestin-only pills and of spermicides are 9% and 28% per year, respectively, as compared with failure rates of less than 1% per year for copper-containing intrauterine devices and levonorgestrel-releasing intrauterine devices.

B) CORRECT:

Progestin-only contraceptive pills, spermicides, and intrauterine devices (both copper-containing and progesterone-based) are all safe for women with hypertension. However, the failure rates associated with typical use of progestin-only pills and of spermicides are 9% and 28% per year, respectively, as compared with failure rates of less than 1% per year for copper-containing intrauterine devices and levonorgestrel-releasing intrauterine devices. Thus, an intrauterine device is the safest, most effective choice for a woman with uncontrolled hypertension.

Estrogen-containing contraception is contraindicated in women with uncontrolled hypertension because of an increased risk of myocardial infarction, ischemic stroke, and venous thromboembolism. Estrogen-containing contraceptives include combined hormonal contraceptive pills, the vaginal ring, and all contraceptive patches.

Key learning point: Uncontrolled hypertension is a contraindication to contraception containing estrogen.

C) INCORRECT:

Estrogen-containing contraception is contraindicated in women with uncontrolled hypertension because of an increased risk of myocardial infarction, ischemic stroke, and venous thromboembolism. Estrogen-containing contraceptives include combined hormonal contraceptive pills, the vaginal ring, and all contraceptive patches.

D) INCORRECT:

Estrogen-containing contraception is contraindicated in women with uncontrolled hypertension because of an increased risk of myocardial infarction, ischemic stroke, and venous thromboembolism. Estrogen-containing contraceptives include combined hormonal contraceptive pills, the vaginal ring, and all contraceptive patches.

E) INCORRECT:

Progestin-only contraceptive pills, spermicides, and intrauterine devices (both copper-containing and progesterone-based) are all safe for women with hypertension. However, the failure rates associated with typical use of progestin-only pills and of spermicides are 9% and 28% per year, respectively, as compared with failure rates of less than 1% per year for copper-containing intrauterine devices and levonorgestrel-releasing intrauterine devices.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old young woman wants to discuss contraception. She has been sexually active for one year, with a total of three male partners. She uses condoms 75% of the time and has never been pregnant. She has not had intercourse during the past 3 months and would like to start a new contraceptive method before having sex with her new male partner. Effectiveness is her greatest concern.
The patient takes no medications, has no ongoing medical issues, and has an unremarkable family history. Six months ago, she was treated successfully for chlamydia infection. She reached menarche at age 13 and has regular menses, lasting 4 days, every 29 to 30 days. Her last menstrual period began 2 days ago.
Her BMI is in the 90th percentile, and her blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg. Her physical examination is normal. Screening tests for chlamydia, gonorrhea, and HIV are negative.
In addition to counseling this patient about the importance of regular condom use in preventing sexually transmitted infections, which one of the following forms of contraception should be recommended to her as most effective?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Women desiring reversible, highly effective contraception may be offered an intrauterine device (IUD) or the etonogestrel implant, which have lower failure rates during typical use than combined hormonal contraceptives such as the vaginal contraceptive ring. Furthermore, estrogen-containing contraceptives (whether oral, patch, or vaginal ring) may negatively affect blood pressure, which is a concern in this patient whose blood pressure is already elevated.

B) INCORRECT:

Women desiring reversible, highly effective contraception may be offered an intrauterine device (IUD) or the etonogestrel implant, which have lower failure rates during typical use than combined hormonal contraceptives such as the patch. Furthermore, estrogen-containing contraceptives (whether oral, patch, or vaginal ring) may negatively affect blood pressure, which is a concern in this patient whose blood pressure is already elevated.

C) INCORRECT:

Women desiring reversible, highly effective contraception may be offered an intrauterine device (IUD) or the etonogestrel implant. Both of these contraceptives have lower failure rates during typical use than progestin-only injectables. Furthermore, depot medroxyprogesterone acetate (the most commonly used progestin-only injectable) may cause further weight gain in women with overweight or obesity and is therefore not an ideal choice for this patient.

D) CORRECT:

Women desiring reversible, highly effective contraception may be offered an intrauterine device (IUD) or the etonogestrel implant. Both of these contraceptives have lower failure rates (<1 %) during typical use (which include inconsistent or incorrect self-administration) than any other form of contraception.

IUDs are approved to stay in place for 5 to 10 years depending on the type, and etonogestrel implants are approved to remain in place for 3 years; there is evidence for both of these devices that the contraceptive effect may be longer than the approved duration.

In this particular patient, the IUD is preferred over the etonogestrel implant because there is concern that the implant is less effective in women who are >130% of their ideal body weight and that the implant may be associated with additional weight gain. Before IUD insertion, the clinician should perform a bimanual examination and inspect the cervix to evaluate for mucopurulent discharge, as active cervicitis is a contraindication to IUD placement. IUDs are also contraindicated in cases of puerperal sepsis or septic abortion.

All forms of contraception carry risks. Implants, IUDs, injectables, and hormonal patches can cause irregular menstrual bleeding. Amenorrhea may occur with the levonorgestrel IUD, implants, or injectables. Expulsion of an IUD is a known complication, as is uterine perforation.

Key learning point: The two forms of long-term contraception that are reversible and have “typical-use” failure rates of less than 1% are an etonogestrel implant and a levonorgestrel intrauterine device.

E) INCORRECT:

Women desiring reversible, highly effective contraception may be offered an intrauterine device (IUD) or the etonogestrel implant, which have lower failure rates during typical use than combined oral contraceptives. Furthermore, estrogen-containing contraceptives (whether oral, patch, or vaginal ring) may negatively affect blood pressure, which is a concern in this patient whose blood pressure is already elevated.

The IUD and the etonogestrel implant both have lower failure rates during typical use (which include inconsistent or incorrect self-administration) than any other form of contraception. Typical-use failure rates are <1% for IUDs and implants; 5% to 10% for progestin-only injectables (primarily related to schedule nonadherence); 5% to 10% for combined hormonal contraceptives (oral contraceptives, transdermal patch, vaginal ring); and 15% to 20% for condoms.

All forms of contraception carry risks. Estrogen-containing contraceptives (whether oral, patch, or vaginal ring) may negatively affect blood pressure, which is a concern in a patient whose blood pressure is already elevated.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old gravida 3, para 3 woman presents with her 2-week-old infant for his first examination. She is planning to resume intercourse before her 6-week postpartum visit and asks about effective contraceptive methods.
She is currently breastfeeding and is not planning to have any more children in the next year. She and her husband prefer to avoid condoms.
Which one of the following contraceptive strategies is most appropriate to recommend to this woman?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

VTE risk is increased during pregnancy and the postpartum period — and is also increased with the use of estrogen-containing contraception, including pills, transdermal patches, and vaginal rings. For this reason, estrogen-containing contraception is considered an unacceptable health risk for all postpartum women in the first 40 days after delivery.

B) INCORRECT:

Diaphragms and cervical caps are not considered to be adequate birth control in the immediate postpartum period because the fit for these devices may change during the postpartum period.

C) CORRECT:

Postpartum contraception should be initiated before the expected return of ovulation, which is approximately 6 weeks after the initiation of supplemental feeding in women who are breastfeeding and as early as 4 weeks postpartum in women who are not breastfeeding. When discussing postpartum contraceptive methods, it is important to consider the timing of contraception initiation, the woman's breastfeeding practices, and the risk of venous thromboembolism (VTE).

VTE risk is increased during pregnancy and the postpartum period — and is also increased with the use of estrogen-containing contraception, including pills, transdermal patches, and vaginal rings. For this reason, estrogen-containing contraception is considered an unacceptable health risk for all postpartum women in the first 40 days after delivery.

The safest contraceptive options during the first 40 days postpartum are condoms, copper intrauterine devices (IUDs), and progestin-only contraceptives. Copper IUDs and progesterone-only IUDs are long-acting and reversible. Although recommendations vary on when they should be placed, they can usually be inserted soon after delivery and certainly within the first few weeks postpartum. IUDs have a slightly higher expulsion rate postpartum, but the rate is still low enough that this is an accepted method of birth control.

Neither IUDs nor condoms have any effect on breastfeeding. Progestin-only contraceptives have no adverse effect on breastfeeding, and some (such as depot medroxyprogesterone acetate and progesterone-only pills) may even increase the quality and duration of lactation.

Key learning point: Among women who plan to resume sexual intercourse before the recommended 6 weeks postpartum, the contraceptive methods considered to be safest are condoms, copper intrauterine devices, and progestin-only contraceptives.

D) INCORRECT:

Although combination oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) are not recommended during the first 40 days after delivery, they are generally considered safe to use later in the postpartum period, even in women who are breastfeeding. Traditionally, combination OCPs have not been recommended for women who are breastfeeding because of concerns that the estrogen component might reduce the volume of milk production, as well as the caloric and mineral content of the breast milk. However, once lactation is well established and the VTE risk is reduced, combination OCPs are a safe contraceptive option.

E) INCORRECT:

VTE risk is increased during pregnancy and the postpartum period — and is also increased with the use of estrogen-containing contraception, including pills, transdermal patches, and vaginal rings. For this reason, estrogen-containing contraception is considered an unacceptable health risk for all postpartum women in the first 40 days after delivery.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl comes to the office because she had unprotected sexual intercourse the previous day. She states that she does not wish to become pregnant until she is in her thirties. She is concerned about becoming pregnant and requests the most effective emergency contraception. She has no history of serious illness. Menses have occurred at regular 28-day intervals since menarche at the age of 13 years. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. Body mass index is 31 kg/m2. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation regarding contraception for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral ulipristal acetate is an emergency contraception option with a failure rate of approx. 1%; the failure rate is relatively higher when used in the second half of the menstrual cycle and in individuals with overweight or obesity. For this patient, there is a more appropriate option for emergency contraception that has a lower failure rate and provides long-term contraception.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral levonorgestrel is available for emergency contraception without a prescription and is thus widely used. Studies have shown that oral levonorgestrel has a failure rate of approx. 2% when used as an emergency contraceptive and that the failure rate is relatively higher when used in the second half of the menstrual cycle and in women with overweight or obesity. For this patient, there is a more appropriate option for emergency contraception that has a lower failure rate and provides long-term contraception.

C) INCORRECT:

Although a progestin-containing subcutaneous implant is an excellent option for long-term contraception, this patient also requires emergency contraception, for which progestin-containing implants are neither approved nor recommended. Progestin-containing intrauterine devices, however, are an effective form of both emergency and long-term contraception.

D) INCORRECT:

Mifepristone is indicated for the medical abortion of an established pregnancy. Although mifepristone is used for emergency contraception in some countries, it is not currently approved for emergency contraception in the United States.

E) CORRECT:

Copper-containing intrauterine devices (IUDs) have been shown to be the most effective option for emergency contraception, with a failure rate of only approx. 0.1% regardless of the patient's BMI or the timing of emergency contraception with respect to ovulation. Recently, levonorgestrel IUDs have been shown to be just as effective as copper IUDs for emergency contraception and may also be associated with less discomfort. Since IUDs provide long-acting reversible contraception, they are a good option for women who require emergency contraception and do not wish to become pregnant in the near future. If a patient is considering pregnancy in the near future, or if the brief clinical procedure for IUD insertion is not feasible, other options for emergency contraception include oral levonorgestrel or ulipristal acetate, but these options are not as effective as copper or levonorgestrel IUDs, especially if the patient is overweight or obese or if these medications are used after ovulation (i.e., the second half of the menstrual cycle).

Although state laws vary, the majority of states allow minors to make their own decisions regarding contraception services and sexually transmitted infection screening and treatment.
questions.hint: This recommendation would be contraindicated if the patient had Wilson disease.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman comes to the office to discuss contraceptive options. She is currently sexually active with one male partner, and they have not been using any contraception. She has no significant past medical history and takes no medications. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 15 years. She is allergic to latex and copper. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following contraceptive methods is contraindicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The patient should avoid latex diaphragms because of her allergy. However, she could use a silicone or rubber diaphragm with spermicide.

B) INCORRECT:

Although estrogen-containing contraceptives are contraindicated in patients > 35 years with a smoking history (increases the risk of VTE), this woman is still a candidate for progestin-only contraceptives.

C) INCORRECT:

Although this patient reports a copper allergy and would not be a candidate for a copper intrauterine device (IUD), she could still receive a progestin IUD. Progestin IUDs provide long-acting reversible contraception and are also appropriate for smokers older than 35 years of age.

D) INCORRECT:

Although this patient should avoid latex condoms given her allergy, she could use nonlatex (e.g., polyurethane) condoms. With consistent and correct use, condoms have a minimal failure rate. Additionally, they reduce the risk of sexually transmitted infections.

E) CORRECT:

Combined oral contraceptive pills (COCs) are contraindicated in women ≥ 35 years who smoke due to an increased risk of VTE. Estrogen is associated with coagulopathy because it increases the plasma concentrations of several clotting factors and fibrinogen. Advancing age and smoking also affect blood clotting and circulation. Other absolute contraindications for the use of estrogen-containing COCs include cardiovascular diseases (e.g., coronary artery disease, deep vein thrombosis, stroke, hypertension), metabolic disorders (e.g., of the liver, insulin-dependent diabetes), estrogen-dependent tumors, SLE, and/or vasculitis.

Key learning point: Combined oral contraceptive pills are contraindicated in women aged 35 or older who smoke due to an increased risk of venous thromboembolism.
questions.hint: This patient's age and smoking history increase her risk of venous thromboembolism (VTE) if she uses a particular form of contraception.

questions.text: An otherwise healthy 18-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 1-year history of severe acne vulgaris over her face, upper back, and arms. Treatment with oral antibiotics and topical combination therapy with benzoyl peroxide and retinoid has not completely resolved her symptoms. Examination shows oily skin with numerous comedones, pustules, and scarring over the face and upper back. Long-term therapy is started with combined oral contraceptives. This patient's new medication significantly reduces the risk of developing which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Long-term COC use (≥ 5 years) is associated with an increased risk of developing cervical cancer. The mechanism by which they do this is unclear, but it is hypothesized that these medications increase the susceptibility of cervical cells to human papillomavirus infection (the main cause of cervical cancer) and/or decrease the ability of cervical cells to clear this infection.

B) CORRECT:

For female patients with continued severe acne vulgaris despite first-line therapies (e.g., oral antibiotics and topical combination therapy), COCs can be added. Besides having positive effects on acne vulgaris, the progestin contained in COCs opposes estrogen-driven endometrial hyperplasia, which reduces the risk of developing type 1 endometrial cancer. This risk decreases with a longer duration of COC use, and protection persists for many years after drug cessation. COCs also reduce the risk of developing ovarian cancer, possibly through reduced cell proliferation within the ovaries and fallopian tubes.

C) INCORRECT:

COC therapy is associated with an increased risk of developing deep vein thrombosis since estrogen induces transcription of clotting factors (II, VII, VIII, X, XII) and fibrinogen to promote clot formation.

D) INCORRECT:

COC therapy increases the risk of developing hypertension, although this risk minimizes shortly after drug cessation. The mechanism of oral contraception-induced hypertension is unclear but may be related to increased serum angiotensinogen concentrations.

E) INCORRECT:

COC therapy does not reduce the risk of developing breast cancer. However, there is controversy as to whether these medications actually increase the risk of developing breast cancer and, therefore, should be used with caution in patients with high risk for breast cancer development (e.g., due to BRCA mutations).
questions.hint: Progestin, a component of combined oral contraceptives (COCs), opposes the effects of estrogen.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman comes to the office for a follow-up examination. She had a spontaneous abortion 3 months ago. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. She reports feeling sad occasionally but has continued working and attending social events. She does not have any suicidal ideation or tendencies. She does not smoke. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination including pelvic examination shows no abnormalities. A urine pregnancy test is negative. She wants to avoid becoming pregnant for the foreseeable future and is started on combined oral contraceptive pills. Which of the following is the patient at risk of developing?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Certain progestin-only contraceptive pills may increase the incidence of ovarian cysts, but combined oral contraceptive therapy (estrogen-progestin combination) is not known to increase the incidence of functional ovarian cysts.

B) INCORRECT:

Prolonged estrogen stimulation of the endometrium that is unopposed by progesterone (e.g., postmenopausal patients receiving estrogen replacement therapy without progestin) would increase the risk of endometrial cancer. However, combined oral contraceptive therapy (estrogen-progestin combinations) actually decreases the risk of endometrial cancer.

C) INCORRECT:

Despite common belief, oral contraceptives are not known to cause weight gain.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral contraceptive therapy decreases, not increases, the risk of benign breast cysts.

E) CORRECT:

The use of estrogen-containing oral contraceptives increases the risk of cardiovascular side effects such as hypertension and thromboembolism. Estrogen-containing oral contraceptives may also cause hyperlipidemia and a mild increase in the incidence of hepatic adenomas.

The most common adverse effect of oral contraceptives is breakthrough bleedings. Oral contraceptives are not known to cause weight gain or have any long-term effects on fertility.

questions.text: Ten days after delivering a healthy male newborn, a 28-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1, undergoes a postpartum follow-up evaluation. Labor and delivery were uncomplicated. One week after delivery, she was diagnosed with postpartum endometritis, for which she is currently receiving treatment with clindamycin and gentamicin. She had painful swelling of the breasts at the beginning of lactation, but frequent breastfeeding and warm compresses prior to breastfeeding improved her symptoms. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Prior to discharge, the patient asks about a reliable contraceptive method. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation at this time?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Spermicides are among the least effective methods of contraception. They are commonly combined with a diaphragm or cap but are often used incorrectly. Moreover, spermicides can cause vaginal burning, irritation, and allergic reactions. A safer method should be recommended to prevent unintended and short-interval pregnancy in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Intrauterine devices (IUDs) can be inserted as early as immediately postpartum and provide long-acting reversible contraception. While they can easily be removed when a pregnancy is desired, this patient is currently being treated for endometritis, a contraindication to an IUD. The insertion of an IUD is not recommended until the infection has been fully resolved. Other contraindications include genital malignancy, genital bleeding of unknown cause, gestational trophoblastic disease, septic abortion, active vaginitis or pelvic inflammatory disease, and certain uterine anomalies.

C) CORRECT:

Contraceptive pills are a viable option for postpartum contraception. In breastfeeding women, progestin-only contraceptive pills (minipill) or progestin-only implants should be recommended, since estrogen-containing combined contraceptives may reduce breast milk production (by inhibition of prolactin activity) and enter the milk. Estrogen should also be avoided for the first 3 weeks postpartum because of its association with coagulopathy and a generally increased risk of thromboembolic events in the early postpartum period. Progestin prevents pregnancy by increasing the viscosity of cervical mucus and by impairing peristalsis of the fallopian tubes, leading to inhibited sperm ascension and egg implantation. In addition, it inhibits follicular maturation and may suppress ovulation. An intrauterine device is also a reasonable option in the postpartum period, but not in patients with active pelvic infection.

D) INCORRECT:

Combined oral contraceptives (COCs) containing estrogen and progestin are contraindicated in this patient, since estrogen may reduce breast milk production and enter the milk. Moreover, estrogen increases an already existing risk of venous thromboembolism (VTE) in the early postpartum period even further. COCs can be started safely after 4–6 weeks postpartum, when the VTE risk is declining to baseline, lactation is well established, and there is no longer a close relationship between the amount of prolactin and the amount of milk produced.

E) INCORRECT:

Breastfeeding causes lactational amenorrhea by suckling-induced disruption of GnRH and LH release, preventing ovulation, and is used as a contraceptive method by some women (lactational amenorrhea method). However, it is not completely reliable and the risk of pregnancy increases when the mother starts breastfeeding less often, uses supplement feeding, her period returns, or more than 6 months have passed since delivery. Some women may be fertile again as early as 3 weeks after delivery if they do not fully breastfeed.
questions.hint: It is important to consider this patient's history when evaluating the most appropriate contraceptive method.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman comes to the office for contraceptive counseling. She has recently become sexually active with her boyfriend and expresses concerns because approximately 10 days ago the condom broke during intercourse. Her medical history is significant for deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism. Urine pregnancy test is negative. After discussing different contraceptive options, the patient says, “I'd like to try the most effective method that works without hormones and would allow me to become pregnant at a later time.” The contraceptive method that best meets the patient's wishes has which of the following mechanisms?

choices.text: Preventing passage of semen into the cervix

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fertility awareness-based methods such as abstinence during the fertile period are nonhormonal, side-effect free, and inexpensive. Methods for estimating the fertile period are the calendar method, the cervical mucus method, the basal body temperature method, and the symptothermal method. However, all of these methods are inexact and prone to human error, resulting in a high failure rate. There is a more effective method of contraception that meets this patient's wishes.

B) CORRECT:

Nonhormonal intrauterine devices (IUDs) release copper into the uterine cavity, which induces sterile inflammation of the endometrium. This local inflammatory reaction has spermicidal effects and prevents fertilization. The failure rate of IUDs is around 0.5%, making them one of the most effective contraceptives. Copper IUDs are long-acting reversible contraceptives, and pregnancy is possible after removal. Side effects include increased or irregular menstrual bleeding, dysmenorrhea, ectopic pregnancy, and pelvic inflammatory disease.

The copper IUD is the most effective type of emergency contraception and can be placed up to 5 days post-intercourse.

C) INCORRECT:

Barrier contraceptive methods (e.g., condom, diaphragm, cervical cap, sponge) prevent the passage of semen into the cervix and are nonhormonal contraceptives that can be considered in young women with a history of thrombosis. However, failure rates range from 12–14% and this patient has already been using condoms. There is a more effective method of contraception that meets this patient's wishes.

D) INCORRECT:

Thickening of cervical mucus impairs sperm ascension and is an effect of both progestin-only oral contraceptives (also known as “minipill”) and hormonal intrauterine devices (IUDs). Although neither progestin-only pills nor hormonal IUDs are contraindicated in patients with a history of thrombosis, this patient has explicitly requested a nonhormonal contraceptive method. Additionally, the pregnancy rate in the first year with typical use of the minipill is relatively high (∼ 9%). There is a more effective method of contraception that meets this patient's wishes.

E) INCORRECT:

Prevention of ovulation by inhibiting the release of luteinizing hormone and follicle-stimulating hormone is the mechanism of action of combined (estrogen-progestin) hormonal contraceptives (e.g., combined oral contraceptive, contraceptive patch, vaginal ring). This patient has a history of thrombosis, which is an absolute contraindication for estrogen-containing contraceptives. Progestin-only contraceptives (“minipill”) prevent ovulation in ∼ 60% of cases and are not contraindicated in this patient. However, she has explicitly requested a nonhormonal contraceptive method. Finally, the pregnancy rate in the first year with typical use of both combined and progestin-only contraceptives is relatively high (∼ 9%). There is a more effective method of contraception that meets this patient's wishes.
questions.hint: For a young patient with a history of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism and preference for nonhormonal methods, a reversible contraceptive method such as the copper intrauterine device is most appropriate.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman comes to the office because of bilateral breast pain for the past 4 months. The symptom started after she began taking oral contraceptives prescribed by the clinician. She appears upset and says, “This is ridiculous! Ever since you prescribed me these pills, my breasts hurt almost every day and it is taking a toll on my relationship; my boyfriend can't even get near me.” Breast examination shows mild bilateral diffuse tenderness, with no masses, redness, swelling, or warmth. The clinician apologizes for her pain and explains the risks and benefits of alternative methods of contraception. When the clinician suggests a copper intrauterine device, the patient seems unsure. The patient says she does not want to use nonhormonal alternatives because they are too unsafe. Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the clinician?

choices.text: "Most of my patients in situations like yours have been very happy using this contraceptive method."
"I really recommend trying a nonhormonal contraceptive. They are also very safe if used correctly."
"You seem unsure about the options presented. Would you like me to give you my personal opinion to help you with this decision?"
"Your symptoms are unlikely to be related to the oral contraceptive pill."
"Can you explain to me your understanding of how a copper intrauterine device works?"

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Disclosure of other patients' experiences with a specific medication can influence a patient's decision. In this case, the patient's uncertainties about nonhormonal contraceptives were not acknowledged by the clinician. Instead of mentioning other patients' experiences, the clinician should provide neutral information to empower the patient in the shared decision-making process.

B) INCORRECT:

Breast pain is a common side effect of hormonal contraceptives and would likely resolve if the patient switched to a nonhormonal contraceptive. However, this patient explicitly stated that she is worried about the safety of nonhormonal contraceptives. The patient's preferences should not be dismissed; more information should be provided about the safety of nonhormonal contraceptives.

C) INCORRECT:

Reflecting the patient's feelings to demonstrate listening and understanding is a good method of strengthening the patient-clinician relationship. However, in a shared decision-making process, the clinician should be as objective as possible and provide neutral information about the different options rather than offer personal opinions.

D) INCORRECT:

This statement is incorrect. Breast pain is a common side effect of oral contraceptive pills. Moreover, the patient's opinion should be acknowledged.

E) CORRECT:

Enabling a shared decision-making process by ensuring that a patient understands a treatment or procedure is a key principle in patient-clinician communication. A useful way to uncover possible misunderstandings is by asking the patient for his or her own perspective on a medication or procedure. Other features of shared decision-making include ensuring the patient knows his or her options, providing relevant facts, and encouraging the patient to discuss his or her thoughts about the options.
questions.hint: When counseling on contraception, it is important to explore the patient's preferences and concerns about the different available methods.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl comes to the clinician for a routine health maintenance examination. She recently became sexually active with her boyfriend and requests a prescription for an oral contraception. She lives with her parents. She has smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 2 years. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate response?

choices.text: "I would like to discuss the various contraceptive options that are available."
"I would recommend a multiphasic combination of ethinyl estradiol and norgestimate."
"I would need your parent's permission before I can provide information about contraceptive therapy."
"I would recommend performing a Pap smear, since you have become sexually active."
"I cannot prescribe oral contraceptives if you are currently a smoker."

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Discussing the different contraceptive options and providing the patient with unbiased and objective information should be the first step. Parental consent is not required for providing information to mature minors (in any state), nor for prescribing contraceptives (in most states).

Key learning point: Confidential, nonjudgmental counseling about all contraceptive options should be offered to sexually active minors without requiring parental consent.

B) INCORRECT:

Combined oral contraceptive therapy is a very effective and commonly used contraceptive method. However, the patient should be informed about all contraceptive options so that both patient and health care provider can decide on a suitable contraceptive method together.

C) INCORRECT:

Parental consent is not required in order to provide a minor with information about contraceptive options in any state. In most states, parental consent is also not required for prescribing contraceptive drugs to minors between the ages of 14 and 17 years.

D) INCORRECT:

The USPSTF and ACOG recommend annual screening for chlamydia and gonorrhea in sexually active teens, but a Pap smear is not required until the age of 21 years, even if the patient is sexually active.

E) INCORRECT:

Smoking, in general, is a relative contraindication to oral contraceptives (OCP). It is only an absolute contraindication in patients older than 35 years, but this patient is only 15. While she should be counseled regarding the risks associated with OCP use, specifically in relation to smoking, OCPs are still a viable option for her.
questions.hint: As a health care provider, you should always try to respect privacy, be empathetic, and offer appropriate counseling.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman with recurrent venous thromboembolism presents to the Outpatient Clinic requesting an effective contraceptive method. She is on stable warfarin therapy with a therapeutic INR and does not plan on conceiving soon. She is concerned about heavy or prolonged bleeding and the possibility of another clot. She has no history of abnormal uterine findings. Physical examination is normal.
Which of the following contraceptive options is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Low-dose combined oral contraceptives contain estrogen, which increases the risk of thrombosis by enhancing hepatic synthesis of clotting factors. This risk is significant even at low doses and is not mitigated by warfarin. Estrogen-containing contraceptives are contraindicated in patients with a history of venous thromboembolism.

B) CORRECT:

The progestin-only implant is a suitable contraceptive for a patient with recurrent venous thromboembolism, as it lacks estrogen, which can increase thrombotic risk. Progestin-only methods work by thickening cervical mucus, inhibiting ovulation, and altering the endometrium to prevent implantation. Estrogen-containing contraceptives are contraindicated in this context due to their prothrombotic effects. Additionally, the progestin-only implant does not exacerbate menstrual bleeding, making it appropriate for a patient on warfarin who is concerned about heavy bleeding.

Key learning point: In patients on anticoagulants, progesterone-only contraceptives and permanent methods like bilateral tubal ligation are preferred due to lower risks of thrombosis and bleeding.

C) INCORRECT:

The copper intrauterine device (IUD) is nonhormonal and avoids estrogen-related thrombotic risks. However, it is associated with heavy and prolonged menstrual bleeding, which is problematic for a patient on warfarin concerned about bleeding. This makes the copper IUD unsuitable for this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

The transdermal estrogen-progestin patch delivers systemic estrogen, which can increase thrombotic risk by altering coagulation factor levels. In patients with recurrent venous thromboembolism, the addition of estrogen poses an unacceptable risk of clot formation, despite the patch's efficacy in preventing pregnancy.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old G1P1 woman delivered a healthy neonate vaginally one week ago. She is exclusively breastfeeding and her postpartum course has been uncomplicated. She does not smoke and has no history of thromboembolism or hypertension. She requests effective contraception that she can begin immediately.
Which of the following is the most appropriate contraceptive method at this time?

choices.text: Condom use only until six weeks postpartum

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Intramuscular medroxyprogesterone is a progestin-only contraceptive suitable for lactating women in the early postpartum period. It avoids estrogen, which can decrease milk production, and provides effective, long-acting contraception by suppressing ovulation and altering cervical mucus and the endometrial lining. This method supports adherence with a dosing schedule every three months, minimizing clinic visits during the postpartum phase.

Key learning point: In breastfeeding women, progestin-only contraceptives like Depo-Provera are preferred over combined hormonal contraceptives to avoid interference with lactation.

B) INCORRECT:

The levonorgestrel intrauterine device is effective but typically inserted immediately postpartum or after uterine involution at 4–6 weeks. At one week postpartum, the risk of expulsion is higher due to the ongoing uterine involution process.

C) INCORRECT:

Condoms are safe and nonhormonal but have a higher failure rate compared to other methods. For a patient seeking effective contraception at one week postpartum, relying solely on condoms is suboptimal due to their lower contraceptive efficacy.

D) INCORRECT:

Combined estrogen-progestin oral contraceptives are not recommended immediately postpartum, especially for breastfeeding women. Estrogen can reduce milk supply and increase the risk of venous thromboembolism, which is already elevated in the postpartum period.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl comes to your clinic for a routine health maintenance examination. She reports feeling well and lives at home with her parents. She mentions that her relationship with her parents has been strained because they do not approve of her new boyfriend. She recently became sexually active with her boyfriend and requests a prescription for oral contraception, expressing that she does not want her parents to know. She smokes half a pack of cigarettes daily and does not drink alcohol. Vital signs are normal. Physical examination is normal. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Inform patient that her smoking history disqualifies her for combined oral contraceptives.
Ask patient to obtain parental consent before discussing any contraceptive options.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Smoking, in general, is a relative contraindication to combined oral contraceptives (COC). It is only an absolute contraindication in patients older than 35 years, but this patient is only 16 years of age. She should be counseled regarding the risks associated with OCP use, specifically in relation to smoking; OCPs are still a viable option for her.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral contraceptive pills are a very common and efficient contraceptive method. However, the patient needs to be informed about all contraceptive options so that she can make an informed decision on the suitable contraceptive method.

C) INCORRECT:

Parental consent is not required for providing information about contraceptive options in any province or territory. In most provinces, parental consent is also not required for prescribing contraceptive drugs to mature minors.

D) CORRECT:

Discussing the different contraceptive options and providing the patient with unbiased and objective information should be the first step. Canadian law ensures that youths may confidentially access sexual and reproductive health care (including contraception and STI treatment) provided they’re mature enough to understand the nature and consequences of the treatment. Except in Quebec (minimum age 14) and Newfoundland and Labrador (minimum age 16), no province or territory sets a fixed age of consent for health-care decisions. Instead, under the mature minor doctrine, clinicians assess each adolescent’s capacity on a case-by-case basis, and no parental consent is required if the youth demonstrates understanding.

Key learning point: Sexually active minors should be offered confidential counseling on all effective contraceptive options without requiring parental consent.
questions.hint: As a physician, you should always try to respect privacy, be empathetic, and help in questions of health.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman comes to your clinic because she is concerned about bothersome hair growth on her face and abdomen that has developed over the past 8 years. She does not take any medications. She is 163 cm tall and weighs 85 kg; BMI is 32. On examination, she has coarse dark hair on her upper lip, periumbilical, and periareolar areas. Her external genitalia are normal. Laboratory studies show that her serum follicle-stimulating hormone, luteinizing hormone, and testosterone are within the reference range. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Which one of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy at this time?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Metformin is used in the management of polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) to reduce circulating insulin levels. While effective in PCOS, metformin is not effective in treating patients with IH.

B) INCORRECT:

Flutamide may be used in the management of IH. However, it is not the first-line therapy in the treatment of hirsutism but rather a third-line antiandrogen considered only for patients who have been refractory to at least 6 months of monotherapy with another medication. Spironolactone is considered the first-line antiandrogen used in patients with refractory moderate to severe hirsutism, with finasteride and cyproterone acetate being the second-line antiandrogens.

C) CORRECT:

Combined oral contraceptives are recommended as the first-line therapy for women with hirsutism due to their ability to reduce androgen levels. Estrogen-progestin contraceptives reduce androgen levels by suppression of circulating luteinizing hormone (LH) and stimulation of sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG) levels.

Key learning point: Combined oral contraceptives are the first-line pharmacologic treatment for idiopathic hirsutism because they lower androgen levels by suppressing LH and increasing sex hormone-binding globulin.

D) INCORRECT:

Leuprolide, a gonadotropin-releasing hormone receptor agonist (GnRH agonist), inhibits ovarian androgen secretion and can therefore suppress male pattern hair growth. However, this therapy is not considered first-line management of IH and has a risk of estrogen deficiency.

E) INCORRECT:

Ketoconazole has been used to treat hirsutism in patients with PCOS as it attenuates serum androgen levels at low doses. It also inhibits ovarian steroidogenesis in vitro. However, ketoconazole is not the first-line therapy in treating patients with IH.
questions.hint: This woman presents with slow progression of excessive male pattern hair growth (hirsutism) with normal gonadotropins and testosterone levels without signs of further virilization. This combination is highly suggestive of idiopathic hirsutism (IH).

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman comes to your clinic to discuss contraceptive options. She is sexually active with one male partner and they have not been using contraception. She has no significant past medical history and takes no medications. She has a 15-year history of smoking one pack of cigarettes daily. She is allergic to latex and copper. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Which one of the following contraceptive methods is contraindicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Combined oral contraceptive pills (COCs) are contraindicated in women ≥ 35 years who smoke due to an increased risk of VTE. Estrogen is associated with coagulopathy because it increases the plasma concentrations of several clotting factors and fibrinogen. Advancing age and smoking also affect blood clotting and circulation. Other absolute contraindications for the use of estrogen-containing COCs include cardiovascular diseases (e.g., coronary artery disease, deep vein thrombosis, stroke, hypertension), metabolic disorders (e.g., of the liver, insulin-dependent diabetes), estrogen-dependent tumors, SLE, and/or vasculitis.

Key learning point: Combined oral contraceptive pills are contraindicated in women aged 35 or older who smoke due to an increased risk of venous thromboembolism.

B) INCORRECT:

Although this patient should avoid latex condoms given her allergy, she could use nonlatex (e.g., polyurethane) condoms. With consistent and correct use, condoms have a minimal failure rate. Additionally, they reduce the risk of sexually transmitted infections.

C) INCORRECT:

The patient should avoid latex diaphragms because of her allergy. However, she could use a silicone or rubber diaphragm with spermicide.

D) INCORRECT:

Although estrogen-containing contraceptives are contraindicated in patients > 35 years with a smoking history (increases the risk of VTE), this woman is still a candidate for progestin-only contraceptives.

E) INCORRECT:

Although this patient reports a copper allergy and would not be a candidate for a copper intrauterine device (IUD), she could still receive a progestin IUD. Progestin IUDs provide long-acting reversible contraception and are also appropriate for smokers older than 35 years of age.
questions.hint: This patient's age and smoking history increase her risk of venous thromboembolism (VTE) if she uses a particular form of contraception.

questions.text: An 18-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 1-year history of severe acne vulgaris affecting her face, upper back, and arms. Previous treatment with oral antibiotics and topical combination therapy with benzoyl peroxide and retinoid has not fully resolved her symptoms. On examination, she has oily skin with numerous comedones, pustules, and scarring over the face and upper back. You initiate long-term therapy with combined oral contraceptives. This new medication significantly reduces the risk of developing which one of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

For female patients with continued severe acne vulgaris despite first-line therapies (e.g., oral antibiotics and topical combination therapy), COCs can be added. Besides having positive effects on acne vulgaris, the progestin contained in COCs opposes estrogen-driven endometrial hyperplasia, which reduces the risk of developing type 1 endometrial cancer. This risk decreases with a longer duration of COC use, and protection persists for many years after drug cessation. COCs also reduce the risk of developing ovarian cancer, possibly through reduced cell proliferation within the ovaries and fallopian tubes.

Key learning point: Combined oral contraceptives reduce the risk of endometrial cancer by opposing estrogen-driven endometrial hyperplasia.

B) INCORRECT:

COC therapy increases the risk of developing hypertension, although this risk minimizes shortly after drug cessation. The mechanism of oral contraception-induced hypertension is unclear but may be related to increased serum angiotensinogen concentrations.

C) INCORRECT:

COC therapy is associated with an increased risk of developing deep vein thrombosis since estrogen induces transcription of clotting factors (II, VII, VIII, X, XII) and fibrinogen to promote clot formation.

D) INCORRECT:

Long-term COC use (≥ 5 years) is associated with an increased risk of developing cervical cancer. The mechanism by which they do this is unclear, but it is hypothesized that these medications increase the susceptibility of cervical cells to human papillomavirus infection (the main cause of cervical cancer) and/or decrease the ability of cervical cells to clear this infection.

E) INCORRECT:

COC therapy does not reduce the risk of developing breast cancer. However, there is controversy as to whether these medications actually increase the risk of developing breast cancer and, therefore, should be used with caution in patients with high risk for breast cancer development (e.g., due to BRCA mutations).
questions.hint: Progestin, a component of combined oral contraceptives (COCs), opposes the effects of estrogen.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman comes to your clinic for follow-up. She had a spontaneous abortion 3 months ago. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. She reports occasional sadness but continues to work and attend social events. She does not have suicidal ideation. She does not smoke. Vital signs are normal. Physical examination, including pelvic examination, is normal. A urine pregnancy test is negative. She wishes to avoid pregnancy for the foreseeable future and is started on combined oral contraceptive pills. Which one of the following is she at risk of developing?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Certain progestin-only contraceptive pills may increase the incidence of ovarian cysts, but combined oral contraceptive therapy (estrogen-progestin combination) is not known to increase the incidence of functional ovarian cysts.

B) INCORRECT:

Despite common belief, oral contraceptives are not known to cause weight gain.

C) CORRECT:

The use of estrogen-containing oral contraceptives increases the risk of cardiovascular side effects such as hypertension and thromboembolism. Estrogen-containing oral contraceptives may also cause hyperlipidemia and a mild increase in the incidence of hepatic adenomas.

The most common adverse effect of oral contraceptives is breakthrough bleedings. Oral contraceptives are not known to cause weight gain or have any long-term effects on fertility.

Key learning point: Estrogen-containing oral contraceptives increase the risk of hypertension and thromboembolic events due to their cardiovascular side effects.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral contraceptive therapy decreases, not increases, the risk of benign breast cysts.

E) INCORRECT:

Prolonged estrogen stimulation of the endometrium that is unopposed by progesterone (e.g., postmenopausal patients receiving estrogen replacement therapy without progestin) would increase the risk of endometrial cancer. However, combined oral contraceptive therapy (estrogen-progestin combinations) actually decreases the risk of endometrial cancer.

questions.text: Ten days after delivering a healthy male newborn, a 28-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1, comes to your clinic for a postpartum follow-up. Her labor and delivery were uncomplicated. One week after delivery, she was diagnosed with postpartum endometritis and is currently being treated with clindamycin and gentamicin. She experienced painful breast swelling at the start of lactation, but her symptoms improved with frequent breastfeeding and warm compresses. Physical examination is normal. Before leaving, she asks you about a reliable contraceptive method. Which one of the following is the most appropriate recommendation at this time?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Spermicides are among the least effective methods of contraception. They are commonly combined with a diaphragm or cap but are often used incorrectly. Moreover, spermicides can cause vaginal burning, irritation, and allergic reactions. A safer method should be recommended to prevent unintended and short-interval pregnancy in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Intrauterine devices (IUDs) can be inserted as early as immediately postpartum and provide long-acting reversible contraception. While they can easily be removed when a pregnancy is desired, this patient is currently being treated for endometritis, a contraindication to an IUD. The insertion of an IUD is not recommended until the infection has been fully resolved. Other contraindications include genital malignancy, genital bleeding of unknown cause, gestational trophoblastic disease, septic abortion, active vaginitis or pelvic inflammatory disease, and certain uterine anomalies.

C) INCORRECT:

Breastfeeding causes lactational amenorrhea by suckling-induced disruption of GnRH and LH release, preventing ovulation, and is used as a contraceptive method by some women (lactational amenorrhea method). However, it is not completely reliable and the risk of pregnancy increases when the mother starts breastfeeding less often, uses supplement feeding, her period returns, or more than 6 months have passed since delivery. Some women may be fertile again as early as 3 weeks after delivery if they do not fully breastfeed.

D) INCORRECT:

Combined oral contraceptives (COCs) containing estrogen and progestin are contraindicated in this patient, since estrogen may reduce breast milk production and enter the milk. Moreover, estrogen increases an already existing risk of venous thromboembolism (VTE) in the early postpartum period even further. COCs can be started safely after 4–6 weeks postpartum, when the VTE risk is declining to baseline, lactation is well established, and there is no longer a close relationship between the amount of prolactin and the amount of milk produced.

E) CORRECT:

Contraceptive pills are a viable option for postpartum contraception. In breastfeeding women, progestin-only contraceptive pills (minipill) or progestin-only implants should be recommended, since estrogen-containing combined contraceptives may reduce breast milk production (by inhibition of prolactin activity) and enter the milk. Estrogen should also be avoided for the first 3 weeks postpartum because of its association with coagulopathy and a generally increased risk of thromboembolic events in the early postpartum period. Progestin prevents pregnancy by increasing the viscosity of cervical mucus and by impairing peristalsis of the fallopian tubes, leading to inhibited sperm ascension and egg implantation. In addition, it inhibits follicular maturation and may suppress ovulation. An intrauterine device is also a reasonable option in the postpartum period, but not in patients with active pelvic infection.

Key learning point: Progestin-only contraceptives are preferred for postpartum breastfeeding women because they do not affect milk production and avoid the increased thromboembolic risk associated with estrogen-containing methods.
questions.hint: It is important to consider this patient's history when evaluating the most appropriate contraceptive method.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman comes to your clinic for contraceptive counseling. She has recently become sexually active with her boyfriend and is concerned because the condom broke during intercourse about 10 days ago. Her medical history includes deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism. A urine pregnancy test is negative. After you discuss various contraceptive options, she states, “I'd like to try the most effective method that works without hormones and would allow me to become pregnant at a later time.” Which one of the following mechanisms best describes the contraceptive method that meets her preferences?

C) INCORRECT:

Fertility awareness-based methods such as abstinence during the fertile period are nonhormonal, side-effect free, and inexpensive. However, all of these methods are inexact and prone to human error, resulting in a high failure rate. There is a more effective method of contraception that meets this patient's wishes.

Side effects include increased or irregular menstrual bleeding, dysmenorrhea, ectopic pregnancy, and pelvic inflammatory disease.

Thickening of cervical mucus impairs sperm ascension and is an effect of both progestin-only oral contraceptives (also known as “minipill”) and hormonal intrauterine devices (IUDs). Additionally, the pregnancy rate in the first year with typical use of the minipill is relatively high (∼ 9%). There is a more effective method of contraception that meets this patient's wishes.
questions.hint: For a young patient with a history of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism and preference for nonhormonal methods, a reversible contraceptive method such as the copper intrauterine device is most appropriate.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl comes to your clinic for a routine health maintenance examination. She recently became sexually active with her boyfriend and is requesting a prescription for oral contraception. She lives with her parents and reports smoking half a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 2 years. Physical examination is normal. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Which one of the following is the most appropriate response?

choices.text: "I would recommend a multiphasic combination of ethinyl estradiol and norgestimate."
"I would recommend performing a Pap smear, since you have become sexually active."
"I would like to discuss the various contraceptive options that are available."
"I cannot prescribe oral contraceptives if you are currently a smoker."
"I would need your parent's permission before I can provide information about contraceptive therapy."

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral contraceptive pills are a very common and efficient contraceptive method. However, the patient needs to be informed about all contraceptive options so that she can make an informed decision on the suitable contraceptive method.

B) INCORRECT:

While annual chlamydia and gonorrhea screening is recommended by the 2025 PHAC guidelines for sexually active individuals under the age of 25 years (and under age 30 per the 2021 CTFPHC guidelines), Pap smears are deferred until the age of 25 years regardless of sexual activity.

C) CORRECT:

Discussing the different contraceptive options and providing the patient with unbiased and objective information should be the first step. Canadian law ensures that youths may confidentially access sexual and reproductive health care (including contraception and STI treatment) provided they’re mature enough to understand the nature and consequences of the treatment. Except in Quebec (minimum age 14) and Newfoundland and Labrador (minimum age 16), no province or territory sets a fixed age of consent for health-care decisions. Instead, under the mature minor doctrine, clinicians assess each adolescent’s capacity on a case-by-case basis, and no parental consent is required if the youth demonstrates understanding.

Key learning point: Clinicians should provide unbiased contraceptive counseling to mature minors without requiring parental consent, as minors generally have the right to confidential reproductive health information and services.

D) INCORRECT:

Smoking, in general, is a relative contraindication to oral contraceptives (OCP). It is only an absolute contraindication in patients older than 35 years, but this patient is only 15. While she should be counseled regarding the risks associated with OCP use, specifically in relation to smoking, OCPs are still a viable option for her.

E) INCORRECT:

Parental consent is not required for providing information about contraceptive options in any province or territory. In most provinces, parental consent is also not required for prescribing contraceptive drugs to mature minors.
questions.hint: As a health care provider, you should always try to respect privacy, be empathetic, and offer appropriate counseling.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl comes to your clinic after having unprotected sexual intercourse the previous day. She states that she does not wish to become pregnant until she is in her thirties. She is concerned about pregnancy and requests the most effective emergency contraception. She has no history of serious illness. Her menses have occurred at regular 28-day intervals since menarche at age 13. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. Her BMI is 31. Physical examination is normal. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Which one of the following is the most appropriate recommendation regarding contraception for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral levonorgestrel is available for emergency contraception without a prescription and is thus widely used. Studies have shown that oral levonorgestrel has a failure rate of approx. 2% when used as an emergency contraceptive and that the failure rate is relatively higher when used in the second half of the menstrual cycle and in women with overweight or obesity. For this patient, there is a more appropriate option for emergency contraception that has a lower failure rate and provides long-term contraception.

B) INCORRECT:

Mifepristone is indicated for the medical abortion of an established pregnancy. Although mifepristone is used for emergency contraception in some countries, it is not currently approved for emergency contraception in Canada.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral ulipristal acetate is an emergency contraception option with a failure rate of approx. 1%; the failure rate is relatively higher when used in the second half of the menstrual cycle and in individuals with overweight or obesity. For this patient, there is a more appropriate option for emergency contraception that has a lower failure rate and provides long-term contraception.

D) CORRECT:

Copper-containing intrauterine devices (IUDs) have been shown to be the most effective option for emergency contraception, with a failure rate of only approx. 0.1% regardless of the patient's BMI or the timing of emergency contraception with respect to ovulation. Since IUDs provide long-acting reversible contraception, they are a good option for women who require emergency contraception and do not wish to become pregnant in the near future. If a patient is considering pregnancy in the near future, or if the brief clinical procedure for IUD insertion is not feasible, other options for emergency contraception include oral levonorgestrel or ulipristal acetate, but these options are not as effective as copper IUDs, especially if the patient is overweight or obese or if these medications are used after ovulation (i.e., the second half of the menstrual cycle).

Canadian law ensures that youths may confidentially access sexual and reproductive health care (including contraception and STI treatment) provided they’re mature enough to understand the nature and consequences of the treatment.

Key learning point: The copper intrauterine device is the most effective method of emergency contraception and also provides long-term reversible pregnancy prevention.

E) INCORRECT:

Although a progestin-containing subcutaneous implant is an excellent option for long-term contraception, this patient also requires emergency contraception, for which progestin-containing implants are neither approved nor recommended.
questions.hint: This recommendation would be contraindicated if the patient had Wilson disease.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the emergency department requesting emergency contraception after unprotected intercourse approximately 65 hours ago. She has regular menstrual cycles and no history of chronic illness. She weighs 110 kg (242 pounds), is a nonsmoker, and has a negative urine pregnancy test in the ED. She is not currently using any form of contraception and expresses interest in initiating longer-term pregnancy prevention. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation?

choices.text: Prescribe levonorgestrel 1.5 mg orally and and schedule contraceptive counseling follow-up
Inform them that emergency contraception is no longer effective after 48 hours
Prescribe a combined oral contraceptive pill and advise double dosing for the first 5 days
Prescribe ulipristal acetate 30 mg orally and schedule contraceptive counseling follow-up

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Levonorgestrel is less effective in patients with a BMI ≥ 25 or weight ≥70 kg. In a patient weighing 110 kg, efficacy may be significantly reduced, making this a suboptimal choice.

B) INCORRECT:

Levonorgestrel is effective up to 72 hours after intercourse. Both ulipristal acetate and IUD placement can be used up to 5 days after unprotected sex.

C) INCORRECT:

The Yuzpe regimen for emergency contraception uses specific, high-dose combinations of estrogen and progestin tablets taken within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse; not simply doubling of a standard contraceptive pill.

D) CORRECT:

Correct — The copper IUD is the most effective form of emergency contraception and maintains efficacy regardless of body weight. It also provides immediate, long-term contraception. It should be strongly considered in patients with higher body mass for whom oral options may be less reliable.

E) INCORRECT:

Ulipristal is more effective than levonorgestrel in patients with elevated BMI, but its efficacy also decreases with weight ≥ 85 kg.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman comes to the physician because of bilateral breast pain for the past 4 months. The symptom started after she began taking oral contraceptives. Breast examination shows mild bilateral diffuse tenderness and no masses, redness, swelling, or warmth of the breasts. The physician explains the risks and benefits of alternative methods of contraception. When the physician suggests a copper intrauterine device, the patient seems unsure. The patient says she does not want to use nonhormonal alternatives because they are too unsafe. Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the physician?

choices.text: "Can you explain to me your understanding of how a copper intrauterine device works?"
"You seem unsure about the options presented. Would you like me to give you my personal opinion to help you with this decision?"
"I really recommend trying a nonhormonal contraceptive. They are also very safe if used correctly."
"Most of my patients in situations like yours have been very happy using this contraceptive method."
"Your symptoms are unlikely to be related to the oral contraceptive pill."

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Enabling a shared decision-making process by ensuring that a patient understands a treatment or procedure is a key principle in patient-physician communication. A useful way to uncover possible misunderstandings is by asking the patient for his or her own perspective on a medication or procedure. Other features of shared decision-making include ensuring the patient knows his or her options, providing relevant facts, and encouraging the patient to discuss his or her thoughts about the options.

Key learning point: Asking patients to explain their understanding of proposed options confirms comprehension, uncovers misconceptions, and empowers shared decision-making.

B) INCORRECT:

Reflecting the patient's feelings to demonstrate listening and understanding is a good method of strengthening the patient-physician relationship. However, in a shared decision-making process, the physician should be as objective as possible and provide neutral information about the different options rather than offer personal opinions.

C) INCORRECT:

Breast pain is a common side effect of hormonal contraceptives and would likely resolve if the patient switched to a nonhormonal contraceptive. However, this patient explicitly stated that she is worried about the safety of nonhormonal contraceptives. The patient's preferences should not be dismissed; more information should be provided about the safety of nonhormonal contraceptives.

D) INCORRECT:

Disclosure of other patients' experiences with a specific medication can influence a patient's decision. In this case, the patient's uncertainties about nonhormonal contraceptives were not acknowledged by the physician. Instead of mentioning other patients' experiences, the physician should provide neutral information to empower the patient in the shared decision-making process.

E) INCORRECT:

This statement is incorrect. Breast pain is a common side effect of oral contraceptive pills. Moreover, the patient's opinion should be acknowledged.
questions.hint: When counseling on contraception, it is important to explore the patient's preferences and concerns about the different available methods.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old woman presents with 14 months of infertility. Her menstrual cycles last 35–38 days with regular monthly bleeding. She has charted her basal body temperature over two consecutive cycles and observes no mid-cycle temperature rise. She has no significant medical history and is not on any medications. Pelvic examination is normal.
Which of the following best explains her difficulty conceiving?

choices.text: Diminished ovarian reserve leading to early menopause
Normal ovulation with insufficient luteal support

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In women with regular menstrual bleeding, the presence of menses does not confirm ovulation. Basal body temperature (BBT) charting reflects the thermogenic effect of progesterone, which increases body temperature post-ovulation. The absence of a mid-cycle temperature rise in this patient indicates anovulation, leading to an inadequate progesterone surge. Without sufficient progesterone, the endometrium does not undergo the secretory transformation necessary for implantation, contributing to infertility. Additionally, her prolonged cycle lengths support the likelihood of anovulation.

Key learning point: A monophasic basal body temperature pattern indicates anovulation, which is a common cause of infertility in women with regular but long menstrual cycles.

B) INCORRECT:

Diminished ovarian reserve and early menopause are more common in older women or those with risk factors, which are absent in this 27-year-old. Her mildly prolonged cycles with regular bleeding indicate ongoing estrogen production. The absence of a mid-cycle temperature rise suggests anovulation, not diminished ovarian reserve.

C) INCORRECT:

Intrauterine lesions can impair implantation, but this patient's regular bleeding and absence of a mid-cycle temperature rise indicate anovulation. The normal pelvic examination does not support intrauterine lesions, and the lack of a temperature shift is linked to hormonal changes post-ovulation.

D) INCORRECT:

Luteal phase defects involve inadequate progesterone after confirmed ovulation, typically shown by a biphasic BBT pattern. This patient lacks a mid-cycle temperature rise, indicating anovulation rather than a luteal phase defect. Her cycle lengths of 35–38 days further suggest ovulatory dysfunction.
